1999 Seattle WTO protests
Part of the
anti-globalization movement (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-globalization_movement)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTO_protests_in_Seattle_November_30_1999.jpg)
A police officer sprays
pepper spray (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepper_spray)
at the crowd
Date
November 30 – December 3, 1999
Location
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
, Washington, United States
Resulted in
Resignation of Seattle police chief
Norm Stamper (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_Stamper)
;
Increased exposure of the WTO in US media; 157 individuals arrested but released for lack of probable cause or hard evidence; $250,000 paid to the arrested by the city of Seattle; Creation of the
Independent Media Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_Media_Center)

The
1999 Seattle WTO protests
, sometimes referred to as the
Battle of Seattle
,
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-1)
were a series of
anti-globalization (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-globalization_movement)
protests surrounding the
WTO Ministerial Conference of 1999 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_1999)
, where members of the
World Trade Organization (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization)
(WTO) convened at the
Washington State Convention and Trade Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_State_Convention_and_Trade_Center)
in
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
,
Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state))
on November 30, 1999. The Conference was to be the launch of a new millennial round of trade negotiations.
The negotiations were quickly overshadowed by massive street protests outside the hotels and the Washington State Convention and Trade Center. The protests were nicknamed "
N30
", akin to
J18 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnival_Against_Capital)
and similar mobilizations. The large scale of the demonstrations, estimated at no fewer than 40,000 protesters, dwarfed any previous demonstration in the United States against a world meeting of any of the organizations generally associated with
economic globalization (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_globalization)
, such as the WTO, the
International Monetary Fund (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund)
, and the
World Bank (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank)
.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-2)
Organizations and planning
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=1)
]
Planning for the actions began months in advance and included local, national, and international organizations. Among the most notable participants were national and international
nongovernmental organizations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nongovernmental_organization)
(NGOs) such as
Global Exchange (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Exchange)
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-Bogardus-3)
(especially those concerned with labor issues, the environment, and consumer protection), labor unions (including the
AFL–CIO (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AFL%E2%80%93CIO)
), student groups, religion-based groups (
Jubilee 2000 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jubilee_2000)
), and
anarchists (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anarchism)
(some of whom formed a
black bloc (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_bloc)
).
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-4)
The protests also drew support from some political conservatives, such as American presidential candidate and commentator
Pat Buchanan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pat_Buchanan)
.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-5)
The coalition was loose, with some opponent groups focused on opposition to WTO policies (especially those related to
free trade (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_trade)
), with others motivated by prolabor,
anticapitalist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anticapitalist)
, or environmental agendas.  Many of the NGOs represented at the protests came with credentials to participate in the official meetings, while also planning various educational and press events. The AFL–CIO, with cooperation from its member unions, organized a large permitted rally and march from
Seattle Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center)
to
downtown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown,_Seattle,_Washington)
.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTO_protestors,_1999_(20680767813).jpg)
The "turtles": protestors in sea turtle costumes
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTO_protest_sign_(14988892087).jpg)
WTO protest sign depicting the organization trampling on three environmental laws.
However, others were more interested in taking
direct action (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_action)
, including both
civil disobedience (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_disobedience)
and acts of vandalism and property destruction to disrupt the meeting. Several groups were loosely organized together under the
Direct Action Network (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_Action_Network)
(DAN), with a plan to disrupt the meetings by blocking streets and intersections downtown to prevent delegates from reaching the convention center, where the meeting was to be held. The black bloc was not affiliated with DAN, but was responding to the original call for autonomous resistance actions on November 30 issued by
People's Global Action (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peoples_Global_Action)
.
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-6)
Of the different coalitions that aligned in protest were the "teamsters and turtles" – a blue–green alliance consisting of the
teamsters (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teamsters)
(trade unions) and environmentalists.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-7)
Corporations targeted
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=2)
]
Certain activists, including locals and an additional group of anarchists from
Eugene, Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eugene,_Oregon)
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-time-8)
(where they had gathered that summer for a music festival),
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-eugeneriot-9)
advocated more confrontational tactics, and conducted
vandalism (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism)
of corporate
properties (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Property)
in downtown Seattle. In a subsequent communique, they listed the particular corporations targeted, which they considered to have committed corporate crime.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-10)
Lead-up months
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=3)
]
On July 12, the
Financial Times (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_Times)
reported that the latest United Nations Human Development report advocated "principles of performance for multinationals on labour standards, fair trade and environmental protection ... needed to counter the negative effects of globalisation on the poorest nations". The report itself argued, "An essential aspect of global governance is responsibility to people—to equity, to justice, to enlarging the choices of all".
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-11)
On July 16, Helene Cooper of
The Wall Street Journal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal)
warned of an impending "massive mobilization against globalization" being planned for the end-of-year Seattle WTO conference.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-12)
Next day, the London
Independent (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Independent)
newspaper savaged the WTO and appeared to side with the organizers of the rapidly developing storm of protest:
The way it has used [its] powers is leading to a growing suspicion that its initials should really stand for World Take Over. In a series of rulings it has struck down measures to help the world's poor, protect the environment, and safeguard health in the interests of private—usually American—companies.
"The WTO seems to be on a crusade to increase private profit at the expense of all other considerations, including the well-being and quality of life of the mass of the world's people," says Ronnie Hall, trade campaigner at Friends of the Earth International. "It seems to have a relentless drive to extend its power."
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-13)
On November 16, two weeks before the conference, President
Bill Clinton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Clinton)
issued Executive Order 13141—Environmental Review of Trade Agreements,
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-14)
which committed the United States to a policy of "assessment and consideration of the environmental impacts of trade agreements" and stated, "Trade agreements should contribute to the broader goal of sustainable development."
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Anarchists_at_WTO_protest_(14988709689).jpg)
Black bloc (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_bloc)
organizing during WTO protests
Activists staged a spoof of Seattle daily newspaper the
Post-Intelligencer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Post-Intelligencer)
on Wednesday November 24, inserting thousands of hoax editions of a four-page front-page wrap-around into piles of newspapers awaiting distribution to hundreds of street boxes and retail outlets. The spoof front-page stories were "Boeing to move overseas" (to Indonesia) and "Clinton pledges help for poorest nations".
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-15)
The byline on the Boeing story attributed it to
Joe Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joe_Hill_(activist))
(a union organizer who had been executed by firing squad in Utah in 1915). On the same day, the International Centre for Trade and Sustainable Development reported:
developing countries have remained steadfast in their demand that developed countries honour Uruguay Round commitments before moving forward full force with new trade negotiations. Specifically, developing countries are concerned over developed countries' compliance with agreements on market access for textiles, their use of antidumping measures against developing countries' exports, and over-implementation of the WTO Agreement on Trade Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs).
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-16)
N30
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=4)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTO_Protests-Seattle-Marchers-29Nov1999.jpg)
Protesters march against the World Trade Organization, Seattle, November 29, 1999.
On the morning of Tuesday, November 30, 1999, the DAN's plan was put into effect. Several hundred activists arrived in the deserted streets near the convention center and began to take control of key intersections. Over the next few hours, a number of marchers began to converge on the area from different directions. These included a student march from the north, a march of citizens of the developing world who marched in from the south and, beginning around 09:00, militant anarchists (in a formation known as a
black bloc (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_bloc)
) marching down Pike Street from 6th Avenue, blockading the streets with newspaper boxes and smashing windows.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-depts.washington.edu-17)
Some demonstrators held rallies, others held teach-ins and at least one group staged an early-morning street party. Meanwhile, a number of protesters still controlled the intersections using lockdown formations.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WTO_protests.jpg)
Seattle police on Union Street, during the protests
That morning, the
King County Sheriff's Office (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_County_Sheriff%27s_Office)
and
Seattle Police Department (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Police_Department)
fired
pepper spray (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pepper_spray)
,
tear gas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tear_gas)
canisters, and
stun grenades (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stun_grenade)
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-BBC12299-18)
at protesters at several intersections in an attempt to reopen the blocked streets and allow as many WTO delegates as possible through the blockade.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-19)
At 6th Avenue and Union Street, the crowd threw objects back at the police.
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-HL2142-20)
By late morning, the black bloc had swelled to 200 people and smashed dozens of shops and police cars. This seems to have set off a chain reaction of sorts, with previously nonviolent protesters throwing bottles at police and joining in the vandalism shortly before noon.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-depts.washington.edu-17)
The police were eventually overwhelmed by the mass of protesters downtown, including many who had chained themselves together and were blocking intersections. Meanwhile, the late-morning labor-organized rally and march drew tens of thousands; though the intended march route had them turning back before they reached the convention center, some ignored the marshals and joined what had become a chaotic scene downtown.
At noon, the opening ceremony at the convention center was officially canceled.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-depts.washington.edu-17)
It took police much of the afternoon and evening to clear the streets. Seattle mayor
Paul Schell (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Schell)
declared a state of emergency, imposed a
curfew (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curfew)
, and a 50-block "no-protest zone."
December 1
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=5)
]
Overnight, the
governor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Governor)
of
Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state))
,
Gary Locke (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gary_Locke)
, called in two
battalions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battalion)
of
Army National Guardsmen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Army_National_Guard)
, other law enforcement agencies sent support, and before daylight on Wednesday, troops and officers lined the perimeter of the no-protest zone. Police surrounded and arrested several groups of would-be protesters (and more than one bystander).  Beginning at 21:00, a major clash took place on Broadway in the vicinity of Denny Way, involving rocks, bottles, and police concussion grenades.  It did not involve a black bloc, but appears to have included local residents, although it is known that many local residents were treated as protesters, even being teargassed, despite having no part in the protests. Police called in from other cities mistook the typically crowded streets of Capitol Hill as groups of protesters.
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-21)
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-22)
More than 500 people were jailed on Wednesday. Throughout the day, police used tear gas to disperse crowds downtown, although a permitted demonstration organized by the Steelworkers Union was held along the waterfront.
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-23)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:National_Guard,_Downtown_Seattle,_WTO_1999.jpg)
Army National Guardsmen marching to their next assignment
December 2–3
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=6)
]
Protests continued the following days. Thousands demonstrated outside the Seattle Police Department protesting their tactics and arrests of peaceful protestors. President Clinton arrived and attended the conference. On December 3 the conference ended as delegations were unable to reach agreements, partly in response to the protests.
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-24)
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-25)
Confrontations with the police continued, albeit at a lower intensity. The primary goal of disrupting the trade talks achieved, some sought the horizons of possibility; it was determined quickly that the necessary ambition to achieve the broader goals of various anarchist factions was not sufficient.
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-26)
Media response
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=7)
]
The New York Times (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times)
published false reports that protesters threw
Molotov cocktails (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molotov_cocktail)
at police.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-27)
Two days later, the
Times
printed a correction saying that the protest was mostly peaceful and no protesters were accused of throwing objects at delegates or the police, but the original error persisted in later accounts in the mainstream media.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-28)
The
Seattle City Council (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_City_Council)
dispelled the reports with its own investigation findings:
The level of panic among police is evident from radio communication and from their inflated crowd estimates, which exceed the numbers shown on news videotapes. ARC investigators found the rumors of "Molotov cocktails" and sale of flammables from a supermarket had no basis in fact. But, rumors were important in contributing to the police sense of being besieged and in considerable danger.
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-29)
An article in the magazine
The Nation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Nation)
disputed that Molotov cocktails have ever been thrown at an antiglobalization protest within the United States.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-30)
Though media coverage of the protests condemned the violence of some of the protesters, the nature of this violence has been justified by some people. Specifically, the violence employed was not person-to-person violence, but "acts directed toward property, not people".
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeLucaPeeples2002-31)
Though many still denounced the violent tactics used by protesters, this violence clearly resulted in increased media coverage of the event. The WTO meeting had an increase in evening news airtime from 10 minutes and 40 seconds on the first day of the meeting to 17 minutes on the first day of violence. In addition, WTO coverage was the lead or second story on
CNN (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN)
,
ABC (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABC_News_(United_States))
,
CBS (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS_News)
, and
NBC (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC_News)
after violence was reported. Two days after the start of violence, the meeting remained the top story on three of the four networks.
Though these numbers alone are telling, the media coverage of subsequent demonstrations that did not include violence by protesters shows even more the effect of violence on coverage. For example, the World Bank/International Monetary Fund (WB/
IMF (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IMF)
) meetings in the spring showed a "coverage pattern that was almost the reverse of that in Seattle" and that "suggests the crucial role of violence in garnering time on the public screen." In an even more striking example of the effects of violence on media coverage, the 2001 WTO meeting in Doha, Qatar, included no reports of violence. As a result, "there was absolutely no TV evening news coverage by the four major networks."
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeLucaPeeples2002-31)
This coverage did not center exclusively on the violence. Instead, details of the protesters' message and antiglobalization campaign were included along with the discussions of symbolic violence taking place. It is said that the violence served as a dense surface that opened viewers' and readers' minds to a whole new way of thinking about globalization and corporations' operations. That is, not only was this violence contained within the familiar setting of television, and not only did it meet the criteria of being dramatic and emotional enough to warrant air time, but it also shattered preconceived notions of globalization and the practices of corporations that drive so much of America's economy.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeLucaPeeples2002-31)
Aftermath
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=1999_Seattle_WTO_protests&action=edit&section=8)
]
To many in North American anarchist and radical circles, the Seattle WTO riots, protests, and demonstrations were viewed as a success.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-32)
Prior to the "Battle of Seattle", almost no mention was made of "antiglobalization" in the US media, while the protests were seen as having forced the media to report on 'why' anybody would oppose the WTO.
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-33)
Previous mass demonstrations had taken place in Australia in December 1997, in which newly formed grass-roots organizations blockaded Melbourne,
Perth (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perth)
, Sydney, and
Darwin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darwin,_Northern_Territory)
city centers.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-34)
Controversy over the city's response to the protests resulted in the resignation of the police chief of Seattle,
Norm Stamper (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_Stamper)
,
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-35)
and arguably played a role in Schell's loss to
Greg Nickels (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greg_Nickels)
in the 2001 mayoral primary election.
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-36)
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-37)
The massive size of the protest added $3 million to the city's estimated meeting budget of $6 million, partly due to city cleanup and police overtime bills. In addition, the damage to commercial businesses from
vandalism (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalism)
and lost sales has been estimated at $20 million.
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-38)
On January 16, 2004, the city of Seattle settled with 157 individuals arrested outside of the no-protest zone during the WTO events, agreeing to pay them a total of $250,000.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-39)
On January 30, 2007, a federal jury found that the city had violated protesters'
Fourth Amendment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution)
constitutional rights (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitutional_rights)
by arresting them without
probable cause (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probable_cause)
or evidence.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-40)
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-41)
Inspired by these protests, a similar one occurred in
Prague (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-globalization_protests_in_Prague)
in September 2000.
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-42)
Around 12,000 activists gathered to protest during the
International Monetary Fund (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund)
and
World Bank (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Bank)
summit on September 27, 2000.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1999_Seattle_WTO_protests#cite_note-43)

The Boeing Company
(
/ˈboʊɪŋ/ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English)
BO-ing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key)
) is an American
multinational corporation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multinational_corporation)
that designs, manufactures, and sells
airplanes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane)
,
rotorcraft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotorcraft)
,
rockets (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocket)
,
satellites (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite)
, and
missiles (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missile)
worldwide.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-6)
The company also provides leasing and product support services. Boeing is among the largest global
aerospace manufacturers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace_manufacturer)
; it is the fourth-largest
defense contractor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_defense_contractors)
in the world based on 2022 revenue
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-7)
and is the largest exporter in the United States by dollar value.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-8)
Boeing was founded by
William E. Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_E._Boeing)
in
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
, Washington, on July 15, 1916.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Boeing-9)
The present corporation is the result of the merger of Boeing with
McDonnell Douglas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas)
on August 1, 1997.
As of 2023, the Boeing Company's corporate headquarters is located in the
Crystal City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crystal_City,_Virginia)
neighborhood of
Arlington County, Virginia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia)
.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-10)
The company is organized into three primary divisions:
Boeing Commercial Airplanes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Commercial_Airplanes)
(BCA),
Boeing Defense, Space & Security (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Defense,_Space_%26_Security)
(BDS), and
Boeing Global Services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Global_Services)
(BGS). In 2021, Boeing recorded $62.3
billion in sales.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-11)
Boeing is ranked 54th on the
Fortune500 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_500)
list (2020),
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-12)
and ranked 121st on the
FortuneGlobal 500 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_Global_500)
list (2020).
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-13)
History
Main article:
History of Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Boeing)
Origins
The Boeing Company started in 1916, when American lumber industrialist
William E. Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_E._Boeing)
founded Pacific Aero Products Company in Seattle, Washington. Shortly before doing so, he and Conrad Westervelt created the
"B&W" seaplane (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Model_1)
.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-14)
In 1917, the organization was renamed Boeing Airplane Company, with William Boeing forming Boeing Airplane & Transport Corporation in 1928.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-15)
In 1929, the company was renamed
United Aircraft and Transport Corporation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Aircraft_and_Transport_Corporation)
, followed by the acquisition of several aircraft makers such as Avion, Chance
Vought (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vought)
,
Sikorsky Aviation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikorsky_Aircraft)
,
Stearman Aircraft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stearman_Aircraft)
,
Pratt & Whitney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pratt_%26_Whitney)
, and Hamilton Metalplane.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Britannica_Boe-3)
In 1931, the group merged its four smaller airlines into
United Airlines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Airlines)
. In 1934, aircraft manufacturing was required to be separate from air transportation.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Encyclopedia_Britannica-16)
Therefore, Boeing Airplane Company became one of three major groups to arise from the dissolution of United Aircraft and Transport; the other two entities were
United Aircraft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Aircraft)
(later
United Technologies (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Technologies)
) and United Airlines.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Britannica_Boe-3)
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Encyclopedia_Britannica-16)
In 1960, the company bought
Vertol Aircraft Corporation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piasecki_Helicopter)
, which at the time, was the biggest independent manufacturer of
helicopters (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helicopter)
.
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-17)
During the 1960s and 1970s, the company diversified into industries such as outer space travel, marine craft, agriculture, energy production and transit systems.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Britannica_Boe-3)
Sea Launch
In 1995, Boeing partnered with Russian, Ukrainian, and Anglo-Norwegian organizations to create
Sea Launch (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sea_Launch)
, a company providing commercial launch services sending satellites to geostationary orbit from floating platforms.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-18)
In 2000, Boeing acquired the satellite segment of
Hughes Electronics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hughes_Electronics)
.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Britannica_Boe-3)
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-19)
Merger with McDonnell Douglas
In December 1996, Boeing announced its intention to merge with
McDonnell Douglas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas)
, which, following regulatory approval, was completed on August 4, 1997.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-20)
The delay was caused by objections from the
European Commission (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Commission)
, which ultimately placed three conditions on the merger: exclusivity agreements with three US airlines would be terminated, separate accounts would be maintained for the McDonnell-Douglas civil aircraft business, and some defense patents were to be made available to competitors.
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-21)
In 2020,
Quartz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quartz_(publication))
reported that after the merger there was a "clash of corporate cultures, where Boeing's engineers and McDonnell Douglas's bean-counters went head-to-head", which the latter won, and that this may have contributed to the events leading up to the 737 MAX crash crisis.
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-frost-22)
Corporate headquarters moves
Boeing's corporate headquarters moved from Seattle to Chicago in 2001.
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-23)
In 2018, the company opened its first factory in Europe at
Sheffield (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheffield)
, UK, reinforced by a research partnership with the
University of Sheffield (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Sheffield)
.
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-24)
In May 2020, the company cut over 12,000 jobs due to the drop in air travel during the
COVID-19 pandemic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic)
with plans for a total 10% cut of its workforce or approximately 16,000 positions.
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-25)
In July 2020, Boeing reported a loss of $2.4 billion as a result of the pandemic and the
Boeing 737 MAX groundings (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX_groundings)
, and that it was in response planning to make more job and production cuts.
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-26)
On August 18, 2020, CEO Dave Calhoun announced further job cuts;
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-27)
on October 28, 2020, nearly 30,000 employees were laid off, as the airplane manufacturer was increasingly losing money due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-28)
In May 2022, Boeing announced plans to transfer its global headquarters from Chicago to
Arlington, Virginia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington,_Virginia)
, a suburb of Washington, D.C. The company said that this decision was made in part to concentrate on its defense work with "proximity to our customers and stakeholders".
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Boe_HQ_move-29)
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Wash_Post_HQ_move-30)
After the January 2024
Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines_Flight_1282)
and other incidents, one shareholder proposed relocating the corporate headquarters back to the Seattle area in hopes of getting engineering and quality control teams on-site access to key decision-makers. Boeing's board soundly dismissed the attempt.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-31)
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-32)
In February 2023, Boeing announced plans for laying off approximately 2,000 of its workers from finances and human resources.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-33)
In May 2023, Boeing acquired autonomous
eVTOL (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EVTOL)
air taxi startup
Wisk Aero (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wisk_Aero)
.
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-acq-34)
In June 2024, Boeing agreed to re-acquire
Spirit AeroSystems (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spirit_AeroSystems)
, its longtime supplier of airplane parts, which had been established in 2005 when Boeing
spun-off (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_spin-off)
its Wichita division to an investment firm. The deal was initially discussed in March of the same year before being closed on June 30 at $4.7 billion.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-35)
Labor strike
See also:
2024 Boeing machinists strike (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Boeing_machinists_strike)
On September 12, 2024, a vote was held among Boeing machinist workers who are also members of the
International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_of_Machinists_and_Aerospace_Workers)
(IAM) labor union, with 94.6% of participating members rejected a contract offer that the union's bargaining committee had endorsed, with 96% voting to strike.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-firststrikesince2008-36)
At 12:01 am on September 13, Boeing workers went on strike for the first time since 2008.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-firststrikesince2008-36)
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-37)
On October 12, 2024, the company announced plans to cut 17,000 jobs, about 10% of its global workforce, "to align with our financial reality". It would also delay the first deliveries of its 777X airliner by a year and recorded $5 billion in losses in the third quarter of the year.
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-38)
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-39)
On October 28, Boeing initiated a significant share sale, valued at nearly $19 billion, to address cash-flow issues and avoid a potential downgrade to
junk status (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_rating#Corporate_credit_ratings)
.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-40)
On November 1, 2024, the IAM endorsed an improved contract offer which would see a 38% pay rise over four years, a $12,000 ratification bonus, and the reinstatement of an annual bonus scheme.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-41)
On November 5, 2024, Boeing workers accepted the pay deal, ending a seven-week-long walk out.
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-42)
Divisions
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Boeing_Plant_in_Renton,_5-18-2010_(4622746048).jpg)
Assembly of a
737 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737)
in the
Boeing Renton Factory (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Renton_Factory)
The company's three divisions are: Commercial Airplanes; Defense, Space & Security; and Global Services.
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Brief-43)
Boeing Commercial Airplanes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Commercial_Airplanes)
(BCA) builds commercial aircraft including the
737 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737)
,
767 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_767)
,
777 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_777)
, and
787 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_787_Dreamliner)
along with freighter and
business jet (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Business_Jet)
variants of most. The division employs nearly 35,000 people, many working at the company's manufacturing facilities in
Everett (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Everett_Factory)
and
Renton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Renton_Factory)
, Washington (outside of
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
), and
South Carolina (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_South_Carolina)
.
Boeing Defense, Space & Security (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Defense,_Space_%26_Security)
(BDS) builds military airplanes, rotorcraft, and missiles, as well as space systems for both commercial and military customers, including satellites, spacecraft, and rockets.
Boeing Global Services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Global_Services)
(BGS) provides aftermarket support, such as maintenance and upgrades, to customers who purchase equipment from BCA, BDS, or other manufacturers.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Final_assembly_of_Boeing_737_airplane_(1975).jpg)
Final assembly of a Boeing 737 airplane, 1975
Safety defects and airplane crashes
See also:
Boeing manufacturing and design issues (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_manufacturing_and_design_issues)
Boeing 737 MAX crashes and groundings
Main article:
Boeing 737 MAX groundings (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX_groundings)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Lion_Air_Boeing_737-MAX8;_@CGK_2018_(31333957778).jpg)
PK-LQP, the Lion Air aircraft involved
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Airlines_ET-AVJ_takeoff.jpg)
ET-AVJ, the Ethiopian Airlines aircraft involved
In
2018 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lion_Air_Flight_610)
and
2019 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethiopian_Airlines_Flight_302)
, two
Boeing 737 MAX (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX)
narrow-body passenger airplanes crashed, leaving 346 people dead and no survivors. In response, aviation regulators and airlines around the world
grounded all 737 MAX (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX_groundings)
airliners.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-44)
A total of 387 aircraft were grounded.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-45)
Boeing's reputation, business, and financial rating suffered after the groundings, as Boeing's strategy, governance, and focus on profits and cost efficiency were questioned.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-46)
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-47)
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-48)
In 2022,
Netflix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix)
released an exposé,
Downfall: The Case Against Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downfall:_The_Case_Against_Boeing)
, claiming Boeing's corporate merger with McDonnell Douglas led to the crashes through a disintegration of workplace
morale (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morale)
.
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Downfall-49)
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Bramesco-50)
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-51)
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-52)
[52] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-53)
In June 2020, the
Federal Aviation Administration (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Administration)
found several 737 MAX defects that Boeing deferred to fix, in violation of
regulations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Aviation_Regulations)
.
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-54)
In September 2020, the
U.S. House of Representatives (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives)
concluded its own investigation and cited numerous instances where Boeing dismissed employee concerns with a 737 MAX flight stabilizing feature (
MCAS (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maneuvering_Characteristics_Augmentation_System)
) that caused the two fatal accidents, prioritized deadline and budget constraints over
safety (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aviation_safety)
, and lacked transparency in disclosing essential information to the FAA. It further found that the assumption that
simulator training (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulator_training_for_the_Boeing_MAX_737)
would not be necessary had "diminished safety, minimized the value of
pilot training (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_training)
, and inhibited technical design improvements".
[54] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-55)
On January 7, 2021, Boeing
settled (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Settlement_(litigation))
to pay over $2.5 billion after being charged with fraud over the company's hiding of information from the safety regulators: a
criminal monetary penalty (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine_(penalty))
of $243.6 million, $1.77 billion of damages to airline customers, and a $500 million crash-victim beneficiaries fund.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-56)
In September 2022, Boeing was ordered to pay a further $200 million over charges of misleading investors about safety issues related to these crashes.
[56] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-57)
In March 2023, Boeing disputed in court filings that the victims of
Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethiopian_Airlines_Flight_302)
(2019 crash) experienced any pain and suffering in the final six minutes as the plane was nosediving into the ground, arguing that an impact at the "speed of sound" would have died too quickly to be painful. Boeing's claim was described as "preposterous" by
HuffPost (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HuffPost)
:
[57] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-58)
Passengers aboard the plane, the plaintiffs argued in court, "undeniably suffered horrific emotional distress, pain and suffering, and physical impact/injury while they endured extreme G-forces, braced for impact, knew the airplane was malfunctioning, and ultimately plummeted nose-down to the ground at terrifying speed".
While the investigations into the crashes of the 737 MAX were proceeding, the
Boeing 777X (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_777X)
, the company's largest capacity twin jet and the largest ever built, made its maiden flight on January 25, 2020,
[58] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-59)
but also experienced problems. Following an incident during
flight testing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_777X#Testing)
in 2021, the estimated first delivery of the aircraft was delayed until 2024.
[59] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-60)
After
further technical problems (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_777X#2022)
were discovered in the aircraft in 2022, the release was delayed again until 2025, six years after the original date.
[60] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-61)
[61] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-62)
Alaska Airlines Flight 1282
Main article:
Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines_Flight_1282)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:N704AL_2023-10-28_KBFI.jpg)
N704AL, the Alaska Airlines aircraft involved
On January 5, 2024, on
Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines_Flight_1282)
, a door plug blowout
[62] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-63)
[63] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-64)
occurred on a
737 MAX 9 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX#737_MAX_9)
jetliner after the plane had reached just over 16,000 feet, leaving a
door-sized hole in the fuselage (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_737_MAX_groundings#2024)
and the aircraft made an emergency landing at
Portland International Airport (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland_International_Airport)
successfully with several people onboard injured, although all had subsequently been "medically cleared".
[64] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-65)
The FAA mandated immediate inspections of all 737 MAX 9s fitted with door plugs,
thereby grounding (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines_Flight_1282#Aftermath)
171 aircraft.
[65] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-66)
[66] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-67)
[67] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-68)
United Airlines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Airlines)
found loose bolts on jets grounded by the FAA, raising questions about possible systemic problems with the Boeing 737 MAX 9.
[68] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-69)
The FAA announced on January 12 that it was expanding its scrutiny of Boeing, with a production audit of the 737 MAX 9.
[69] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-70)
On February 6, the
National Transportation Safety Board (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Transportation_Safety_Board)
released a preliminary report indicating that four bolts used to secure the panel had been removed, and appeared not to have been replaced, at Boeing's factory in
Renton, Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renton,_Washington)
.
[70] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-71)
In March 2024, the Justice Department opened a criminal investigation into the Alaska Airlines blowout.
[71] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-72)
In March 2024, CEO Dave Calhoun and board chairman Larry Kellner both announced they would be stepping down from their positions.
[72] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-73)
Environmental record
In 2006, the
UCLA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UCLA)
Center for Environmental Risk Reduction released a study showing that Boeing's
Santa Susana Field Laboratory (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Susana_Field_Laboratory)
, a site that was a former Rocketdyne test and development site in the
Simi Hills (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simi_Hills)
of eastern
Ventura County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ventura_County)
in
Southern California (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_California)
, had been contaminated by Rocketdyne with
toxic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toxic)
and
radioactive waste (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radioactive_waste)
. Boeing agreed to a cleanup agreement with the EPA in 2017.
[73] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-74)
Clean-up studies and lawsuits are in progress.
[74] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-75)
Boeing reported that each one of the jets it delivered in 2020 will add one million tons of carbon dioxide to the Earth's atmosphere, on average.
[75] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-76)
On July 19, 2022, Boeing announced a renewed partnership with Mitsubishi to produce
carbon-neutral (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon-neutral)
and sustainable solutions.
[76] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-77)
Jet biofuels
Main articles:
Aviation biofuel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aviation_biofuel)
and
Algae fuel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algae_fuel)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Boeing_Everett_Plant.jpg)
Boeing Everett Factory (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Everett_Factory)
, the assembly facility for most of the company's
wide-body aircraft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wide-body_aircraft)
The airline industry is responsible for about 11% of
greenhouse gases (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greenhouse_gas)
emitted by the U.S. transportation sector.
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-boe_energy-78)
Aviation's share of the greenhouse gas emissions was poised to grow, as air travel increases and ground vehicles use more alternative fuels like
ethanol (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol_fuel)
and
biodiesel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiesel)
.
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-boe_energy-78)
Boeing estimates that
biofuels (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biofuel)
could reduce flight-related greenhouse-gas emissions by 60 to 80%.
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-boe_energy-78)
The solution blends algae fuels with existing
jet fuel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_fuel)
.
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-boe_energy-78)
Boeing executives said the company was collaborating with Brazilian biofuels maker
Tecbio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tecbio)
,
Aquaflow Bionomic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aquaflow_Bionomic)
of New Zealand, and other fuel developers around the world. As of 2007, Boeing had tested six fuels from these companies, and expected to test 20 fuels "by the time we're done evaluating them".
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-boe_energy-78)
Boeing also joined other aviation-related members in the
Algal Biomass Organization (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algal_Biomass_Organization)
(ABO) in June 2008.
[78] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-79)
Air New Zealand (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_New_Zealand)
and Boeing are researching the
jatropha (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jatropha)
plant to see if it is a sustainable alternative to conventional fuel.
[79] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-80)
A two-hour test flight using a 50–50 mixture of the new biofuel with
Jet A-1 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jet_fuel)
in a Rolls-Royce RB-211 engine of a 747–400 was completed on December 30, 2008.
[80] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Jha-2008-81)
The engine was then removed to be studied to identify any differences between the Jatropha blend and regular Jet A1. No effects on performances were found.
[80] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Jha-2008-81)
Political contributions, federal contracts, advocacy and criticism
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Boeing_787-10_rollout_with_President_Trump_(32335755473)_(cropped).jpg)
Boeing CEO
Dennis Muilenburg (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dennis_Muilenburg)
and US President
Donald Trump (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump)
at the
787-10 Dreamliner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_787_Dreamliner)
rollout ceremony in 2017
In 2007 and 2008, the company benefited from over
US$
10 billion of long-term loan guarantees, helping finance the purchase of their commercial aircraft in countries including Brazil, Canada, Ireland, and the
United Arab Emirates (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates)
, from the
Export-Import Bank of the United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Export-Import_Bank_of_the_United_States)
, some 65% of the total loan guarantees the bank made in the period.
[81] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-82)
In 2008 and 2009, Boeing was second on the list of
Top 100 US Federal Contractors (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Top_100_US_Federal_Contractors)
, with contracts totaling
US$
22 billion and
US$
23 billion respectively.
[82] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-83)
[83] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-84)
Between 1995 and early 2021, the company agreed to pay
US$
4.3 billion to settle 84 instances of misconduct, including
US$
615 million in 2006 in relation to illegal hiring of government officials and improper use of proprietary information.
[84] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-85)
[85] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-86)
[86] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-87)
Boeing's spent
US$
16.9 million on
lobbying (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lobbying_in_the_United_States)
expenditures in 2009.
[87] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-88)
[88] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-89)
In the
2008 presidential election (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_United_States_presidential_election)
,
Barack Obama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama)
"was by far the biggest recipient of campaign contributions from Boeing employees and executives, hauling in
US$
197,000 – five times as much as
John McCain (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McCain)
, and more than the top eight Republicans combined".
[89] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Carney-90)
Boeing has a
corporate citizenship (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_citizenship)
program centered on charitable contributions in five areas: education, health,
human services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_services)
,
environment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_environment)
,
the arts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_arts)
, culture, and
civic engagement (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civics)
.
[90] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-91)
In February 2012, Boeing Global Corporate Citizenship partnered with the
Insight Labs (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insight_Labs)
to develop a new model for
foundations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_(non-profit))
to more effectively lead the sectors they serve.
[91] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-92)
The company is a member of the
U.S. Global Leadership Coalition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Global_Leadership_Coalition)
, a Washington D.C.–based coalition of more than 400 major companies and NGOs that advocate a larger International Affairs Budget, which funds American diplomatic and development efforts abroad.
[92] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-93)
A series of
U.S. diplomatic cables (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_diplomatic_cables_release)
show how U.S. diplomats and senior politicians intervene on behalf of Boeing to help boost the company's sales.
[93] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-94)
Boeing secured the highest-ever
tax breaks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_break)
at the state level in 2013.
[94] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-95)
In March 2025, Boeing was awarded a contract to build the U.S. Air Force's most sophisticated fighter, known as
Next Generation Air Dominance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next_Generation_Air_Dominance)
, in a contract worth more than $20 billion.
[95] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-96)
Criticism
In December 2011, the non-partisan organization
Public Campaign (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Campaign#Reports)
criticized Boeing for spending
US$
52.29 million on
lobbying (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lobbying)
and
not paying taxes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_avoidance)
from 2008 to 2010, instead getting
US$
178 million in
tax rebates (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tax_rebate)
, despite making a profit of
US$
9.7 billion, laying off 14,862 workers since 2008, and increasing
executive pay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_pay)
by 31% to
US$
41.9 million in 2010 for its top five executives.
[96] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-97)
Boeing has been accused of unethical practices (in violation of the
Procurement Integrity Act (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Procurement_Integrity_Act)
) while attempting to submit a revised bid to
NASA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA)
for their lunar landing project.
[97] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-98)
War profiteering
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:641,_2024,_F-15SA_Eagle,_Fairford,_Saudi-Arabia_-_9809_(53999077988).jpg)
The
F-15S/SA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas_F-15E_Strike_Eagle)
jetfighters are one of the major combatants that Boeing has sold to the
Saudi Arabia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabia)
. The aircraft are heavily utilized in the
Saudi-led intervention in the Yemeni civil war (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi-led_intervention_in_the_Yemeni_civil_war)
.
The firm has been criticized for
supplying and profiting from wars (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_profiteering)
, including
the war in Yemen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi-led_intervention_in_the_Yemeni_civil_war)
where its missiles were found to be used for indiscriminate attacks, killing many civilians.
[98] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-99)
[99] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-100)
In 2017 Boeing signed a deal with
Saudi Arabia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saudi_Arabia)
which included Saudi Arabia buying military aircraft and guided missile systems.
[100] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-101)
Research has estimated Boeing made between $50 billion to $100 billion in revenue via Israeli weapons contracts from 2009 through 2022, in the years leading up to the
Gaza war (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaza_war)
.
[101] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-102)
In 2023, it was reported that Boeing sent 1,000 small diameter "smart" bombs for the first week of
Israeli air attacks on Gaza (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israeli_bombing_of_the_Gaza_Strip)
, which were shipped from a
US Air Force (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Air_Force)
base by
Israeli Air Force (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israeli_Air_Force)
.
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-103)
During the Gaza war, Boeing's stock prices soared due to additional Israeli weapons contracts,
[103] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-104)
while mass demonstrations sought to interrupt defense supplier summits and block shipments of weapons for the
Israel Defense Forces (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel_Defense_Forces)
at Boeing facilities in
St. Charles, Missouri (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Charles,_Missouri)
,
[104] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-105)
Tukwila, Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tukwila,_Washington)
,
[105] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-106)
and
Gresham, Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gresham,_Oregon)
,
[106] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Foster-107)
due to the mass violations of
International humanitarian law (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_humanitarian_law)
committed by Israel.
[107] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-108)
[108] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-109)
[109] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-110)
Students at
Florida State University (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florida_State_University)
,
[110] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-111)
University of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Washington)
,
[111] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-112)
Saint Louis University (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saint_Louis_University)
,
University of Missouri–St. Louis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Missouri%E2%80%93St._Louis)
, and
Washington University in St. Louis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis)
[112] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-113)
called for their institutions to break partnerships with Boeing.
In 2024, students on
hunger strike (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunger_strike)
at
Brown University (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_University)
named Boeing among the list of corporations to divest from.
[113] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-114)
Five protestors, in opposition to Boeing sales to Israel, were arrested on
felony (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Felony)
charges after blocking entrances to a Boeing facility in
Heath, Ohio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heath,_Ohio)
.
[114] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-115)
The
student union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Students%27_union)
at
Washington University in St. Louis (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis)
passed a resolution calling on the university to divest from Boeing.
[115] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-116)
Israel has used the Boeing manufactured
GBU-39 Small Diameter Bomb (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GBU-39_Small_Diameter_Bomb)
during the Gaza war, including in bombings of a
Rafah refugee tent camp (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tel_al-Sultan_attack)
,
[116] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-117)
the
Al-Sardi school (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Sardi_school_attack)
,
[117] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Wapo_Rafah-118)
and the
Al-Tabaeen school (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Tabaeen_school_attack)
.
[118] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-119)

Between 2010 and 2018, Boeing increased its operating
cash flow (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cash_flow)
from $3 to $15.3
billion, sustaining its
share (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Share_(finance))
price, by negotiating
advance payments (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advance_payment)
from customers and delaying payments to its suppliers. This strategy is sustainable only as long as orders are good and delivery rates are increasing.
[140] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-141)
From 2013 to 2019, Boeing spent over $60 billion on dividends and
stock buybacks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Share_repurchase)
, twice as much as the development costs of the 787.
[141] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-142)
In 2020, Boeing's second quarter revenue was $11.8 billion as a result of the pandemic slump. Due to higher sales in other divisions and an influx in deliveries of commercial jetliners in 2021, second quarter revenue increased by 44%, reaching nearly $17 billion.
[142] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-143)
Revenues decreased 15 percent to $16.9 billion in the second quarter of 2024, compared to the same time period in 2023.
[143] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-144)
The company's operating loss amounted to $1.39 billion and its net loss to $1.43 billion, while plane deliveries fell to 92 (from 136 in 2023).
In 2024, Boeing delivered just 348 aircraft to its customers, its lowest output since the COVID-19 pandemic.
[
clarification needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify)
]
Boeing ended the year with a backlog of 5,595 unfilled orders.

Approximately 1.5% of Boeing employees are in the
Technical Fellowship (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Technical_Fellowship)
program, a program through which Boeing's top engineers and scientists set technical direction for the company.
[146] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-techfellow-147)
The average salary at Boeing was $76,784 in 2011, as reported by former employees.
[147] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Steph.nox-148)
Corporate governance
In 2022,
Rory Kennedy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rory_Kennedy)
made a documentary film,
Downfall: The Case Against Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downfall:_The_Case_Against_Boeing)
, streamed by
Netflix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netflix)
.
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Downfall-49)
She said about the 21st-century history of Boeing "There were many decades when Boeing did extraordinary things by focusing on excellence and safety and ingenuity. Those three virtues were seen as the key to profit. It could work, and beautifully. And then they were taken over by a group that decided Wall Street was the end-all, be-all."
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-Bramesco-50)
On May 5, 2022, Boeing announced that it would be moving its headquarters from Chicago to Arlington, Virginia in the Washington, D.C. metropolitan area. Additionally, it plans to add a research and technology center in
Northern Virginia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Virginia)
.
[148] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-149)
In July 2024, it announced a new CEO,
Kelly Ortberg (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelly_Ortberg)
.
[149] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-150)
[150] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-151)
On August 8, 2024, he met with FAA Administrator Michael Whitaker to discuss the company's future direction. Ortberg has communicated his commitment to reinforcing Boeing's position as an industry leader and has outlined his vision for the company's continued success.
[151] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing#cite_note-152)

"Seattle Fire" redirects here. For Seattle's fire department, see

.
Great Seattle Fire

The
Great Seattle Fire
was a fire that destroyed the entire central business district of
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
,
Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Territory)
, on June 6, 1889. The conflagration lasted for less than a day, burning through the afternoon and into the night, during the same summer as the
Great Spokane Fire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Spokane_Fire)
and the
Great Ellensburg Fire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Ellensburg_Fire)
. Seattle quickly rebuilt using brick buildings that sat 20 feet (6.1 m) above the original street level. Its population swelled during reconstruction, becoming the largest city in the newly admitted state of Washington.
Early Seattle
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=1)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Yesler_Way_looking_west_from_1st_Ave,_June_5,_1889_(CURTIS_2034).jpeg)
Looking west on Mill Street (today's Yesler Way) across Front Street (today's First Avenue) June 5, 1889, one day before this district burned. Korn block on left; Yesler-Leary Building, center; Occidental Hotel, right.
In the fall of 1851, the
Denny Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_Party)
arrived at
Alki Point (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alki_Point,_Seattle)
in what is now the state of
Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state))
. After spending a miserable winter on the western shores of
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
, the party relocated to the eastern shores and established the settlement that eventually became Seattle.
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-1)
Early Seattle was dominated by the logging industry. The combination of a safe
bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay)
and an abundance of
coniferous (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coniferous)
trees made Seattle the perfect location for shipping lumber to California. In 1852,
Henry Yesler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Yesler)
began construction of the first steam-powered mill in the Pacific Northwest.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-2)
Because of the easy access to lumber, nearly every building was constructed of the affordable but combustible timber. Additionally, because the area was at or below sea level, the fledgling town was a frequent victim of massive floods, requiring buildings to be built on wooden stilts. The town also used hollowed out scrap logs propped up on wooden braces as sewer and water pipes, increasing the combustible loading.
Events of the fire
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=2)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Southwest_corner_of_First_Avenue_and_Madison,_Great_Seattle_Fire,_June_6,_1889.jpg)
Looking south on Front St. from Spring St. about one-half hour after the fire started
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aftermath_of_Seattle_fire_of_June_6,_1889_(CURTIS_448).jpeg)
Aftermath of Seattle fire of June 6, 1889, looking east at the ruins of the Occidental Hotel at corner of James St. and Yesler Way
At approximately 2:20 p.m. on June 6, 1889, an accidentally overheated glue pot in a carpentry shop started the most destructive fire in the history of Seattle.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-:0-3)
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-Austin-4)
The next day, the
Seattle Post-Intelligencer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Post-Intelligencer)
, operating out of temporary facilities in the wake of the fire, reported incorrectly that the incident began in "Jim McGough's paint shop, under Smith's boot and shoe store, at the corner of Front and Madison streets, in what was known as the Denny block";
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-P-I_error-5)
a correction two weeks later said that it "actually started in the Clairmont and Company cabinet shop, below McGough's shop in the basement of the Pontius building", but the original error was often repeated, including in
Murray Morgan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murray_Morgan)
's bestselling Seattle history book
Skid Road
(1951).
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-P-I_error-5)
John Back, a 24-year-old Swede,
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-Austin-4)
was heating glue over a gasoline fire when it boiled over, igniting the wood chips and turpentine covering the floor.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-:0-3)
Back attempted to douse the fire with water which spread the fire further.
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-6)
The fire department arrived by 2:45, but by that time the area was so smokey that the source of the fire could not be determined.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-7)
Spread of fire
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=3)
]
Fed by the shop's timber and an unusually dry summer, the blaze erupted and shortly devoured the entire block. A nearby liquor store exploded, and the alcohol fueled the flames. The fire quickly spread north to the Kenyon block and the nearby Madison and Griffith blocks. Wooden boardwalks carried the flames across streets to ignite other blocks.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-mcnair-8)
A combination of ill-preparedness and unfortunate circumstances contributed to the great fire. Seattle's water supply was insufficient in fighting the giant inferno.
Fire hydrants (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_hydrant)
were sparsely located on every other street, usually connected to small pipes.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-UWLib-9)
There were so many hydrants in use during the fire that the water pressure became too weak to combat such a massive blaze. Seattle was also operated by a
volunteer fire department (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volunteer_fire_department)
, which was competent but inadequate in extinguishing the fire.
Magnitude of destruction
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=4)
]
By the morning of June 7, the fire had burned 25 city blocks, including the business district, four of the city's
wharves (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wharf)
, and its railroad terminals.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-10)
The fire would be called the most destructive fire in the history of Seattle.
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-Austin-4)
Despite the massive destruction of property, few to no deaths occurred. Some claim a young boy named James Goin was killed in the blaze although no reliable records have been found from that time.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-11)
However, there were fatalities during the cleanup process. Over 1 million rodents were killed.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-mcnair-8)
Total losses were estimated at nearly $20 million ($700 million in 2024 dollars).
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-12)
Among the businesses affected were:
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-13)
Company

Washington Iron Works (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Iron_Works)
$40,000
$20,000

$45,000

[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aftermath_of_the_Seattle_fire_of_June_6_(SEATTLE_2974_merged_with_SEATTLE_2976).jpg)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aftermath_of_the_Seattle_fire_of_June_6_(SEATTLE_2974_merged_with_SEATTLE_2976).jpg)
Looking toward Elliott Bay from the burned-over district
Reconstruction and recovery
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=5)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MOHAI_-_plates_from_Great_Seattle_Fire.jpg)
This stack of dishes fused together by the fire is on display at Seattle's
Museum of History and Industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_History_and_Industry)
Despite the magnitude of destruction, the rebuilding effort began quickly. Rather than starting over somewhere else, Seattle's citizens chose to rebuild. Seattle rebuilt from the ashes quickly, and the fire killed many rats and other
vermin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vermin)
, thereby eliminating the city's rodent problems.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
A new building ordinance resulted in a downtown of brick and
stone (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_(geology))
buildings, rather than wood.
In the year following the fire Seattle's population actually grew by nearly 20,000 to 40,000 inhabitants from the influx of people helping to recreate the city.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-14)
Supplies and funds came from all over the West Coast to support the relief effort. The population increase made Seattle the largest city in Washington, making it a leading contender in becoming the terminus of the
Great Northern Railway (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Northern_Railway_(U.S.))
.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-15)
Post-fire reform
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Great_Seattle_Fire&action=edit&section=6)
]
Seattle made many improvements in response to the fire. The
Seattle Fire Department (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Fire_Department)
was officially established four months later to replace a volunteer organization with a paid force containing new firehouses and a new chief. The city took control of the water supply, increasing the number of hydrants and adding larger pipes.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-UWLib-9)
The advent of brick buildings to downtown Seattle was one of the many architectural improvements the city made in the wake of the fire. New city ordinances set standards for the thickness of walls and required "division walls" between buildings.
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire#cite_note-16)
The changes became principal features of post-fire construction and are still visible in Seattle's
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle,_Washington)
district today, the present-day location of the fire. At
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle,_Washington)
, guided tours are also available to paying customers. Also at this location, visitors can tour the
Seattle Underground (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Underground)
, where they can visit the original street level (now basement level) of buildings and storefronts that were built after the fire.

University of Washington Libraries Digital Collections (http://content.lib.washington.edu/)
:
Boyd and Braas Photographs (http://digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/cdm/search/collection/boydBraas/searchterm/fire*!boyd%20braas/field/title!digita/mode/all!all/conn/and!and/cosuppress/)
88 photographs, ca. 1888–1893, of early Seattle, including the waterfront and street scenes, the Great Seattle fire of June 6, 1889, Madrona and Leschi parks, Native American hop pickers, and portraits of Seattle pioneers.
Asahel Curtis Photo Company Photographs (https://content.lib.washington.edu/curtisweb/index.html)
Photographs (ca. 1850s–1940) depicting activities in Washington state, the Pacific Northwest, and Alaska and the Klondike.
Prosch Washington Views Album (http://digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/cdm/search/collection/prosch_washington/searchterm/fire/field/subjec/mode/all/conn/and/cosuppress/)
207 images (ca. 1858–1903) collected and annotated by Thomas Prosch, one of Seattle's earliest pioneers. Images document scenes in Eastern Washington especially Chelan and vicinity, images of the waterfront, businesses, residences, and Seattle's early history including the Great Seattle Fire of 1889; see: pp. 48–56.
Seattle Photographs (http://digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/cdm/search/collection/seattle/searchterm/fire/field/all/mode/all/conn/and/order/title/ad/asc)
Ongoing database of over 1,700 historical photographs of Seattle with special emphasis on images depicting neighborhoods, recreational activities including baseball, the Great Seattle Fire of 1889, "The Great Snow of 1916", theaters and transportation.
