Monorail (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center_Monorail)
tracks going through the MoPOP building
The
Museum of Pop Culture
(or
MoPOP
) is a nonprofit museum in
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
, Washington, United States, dedicated to contemporary
popular culture (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_culture)
. It was founded by
Microsoft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)
co-founder
Paul Allen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen)
in 2000 as the Experience Music Project. Since then MoPOP has organized dozens of
exhibits (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition)
, 17 of which have toured across the U.S. and internationally.
The museum—formerly known as
Experience Music Project
,
Experience Music Project and Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame
(or EMP|SFM), and later
EMP Museum
until November 2016—has initiated many public programs including "Sound Off!", an annual 21-and-under battle-of-the-bands that supports the all-ages scene; and "Pop Conference", an annual gathering of academics, critics, musicians, and music buffs.
MoPOP, in collaboration with the
Seattle International Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_International_Film_Festival)
(SIFF), presents the
Science Fiction and Fantasy Short Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_Fiction_Fantasy_Short_Film_Festival)
which takes place every winter. Since 2007, the MoPop celebrates
recording artists (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musician)
with the Founders Award for their noteworthy contributions.
Exhibits and activities
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=1)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Night_Exterior_EMP.jpg)
Nighttime view of MoPOP
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Guitar_Art_at_the_EMP.jpg)
Guitar sculpture at MoPOP
MoPOP is home to numerous exhibits and interactive activity stations as well as
sound sculpture (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sound_art)
and various educational resources:
A 140,000-square-foot (13,000 m
2
) building, designed by
Frank O. Gehry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_O._Gehry)
, housing several galleries and the Sky Church, which features a Barco C7 black package
LED screen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LED_display)
, one of the largest indoor LED screens in the world.
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-1)
Exhibits covering pop culture, from the art of
fantasy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy)
,
horror cinema (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horror_film)
, and
video games (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game)
to
science fiction literature (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_fiction)
and costumes from screen and stage.
Interactive activities are included in galleries like Sound Lab and On Stage where visitors can explore hands-on the tools of rock and roll through instruments, and perform music before a
virtual audience (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_audience)
.
IF VI WAS IX, a guitar sculpture consisting of more than 500
musical instruments (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musical_instrument)
and 30
computers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer)
conceived by British
exhibit designer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exhibition_designer)
Neal Potter and developed by sound sculptor
Trimpin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trimpin)
.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-2)
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-3)
The world's largest collection of
artifacts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artifact_(archaeology))
,
hand-written (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuscript)
lyrics, personal instruments, and original photographs celebrating the music and history of Seattle musician
Jimi Hendrix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix)
and the band
Nirvana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_(band))
.
Educational resources (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instructional_materials)
including MoPOP's Curriculum Connections in-museum workshops and outreach programs; STAR (Student Training in Artistic Reach); Creativity Camps for Kids; Teen Artist Workshops; Write Out of This World, an annual sci-fi and fantasy short story contest for 3rd to 12th graders; and the Hip-Hop Artist Residency.
Public programs such as MoPOP's Science Fiction + Fantasy
Short Film (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short_film)
Festival, Pop Conference, the Youth Advisory Board (YAB), and Sound Off!, the
Pacific Northwest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest)
's premier battle-of-the-bands.
MoPOP was also the location of the first
NIME (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NIME)
workshop's concert and demo program. This subsequently became the annual International Conference on
New Interfaces for Musical Expression (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Interfaces_for_Musical_Expression)
, a venue for research on
music technology (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_technology)
.
Science Fiction Museum
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=2)
]
The Science Fiction Museum and Hall of Fame was founded by Paul Allen and his sister
Jody Patton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jody_Allen)
, and opened to the public on June 18, 2004. It incorporated the Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame which had been established in 1996. The museum was divided into several galleries with themes such as "Homeworld", "Fantastic Voyages", "Brave New Worlds", and "Them!", each displaying related memorabilia (movie props, first editions, costumes, and models) in large display cases, posters, and interactive displays. It was said about the museum that "From robots to jet packs to space suits and ray guns, it's all here."
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-NYT-4)
Members of the museum's advisory board included
Steven Spielberg (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steven_Spielberg)
,
Ray Bradbury (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_Bradbury)
,
James Cameron (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Cameron)
, and
George Lucas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Lucas)
. Among its collection of artifacts were
Captain Kirk (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_T._Kirk)
's command chair from
Star Trek (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Trek)
, the B9 robot from
Lost in Space (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lost_in_Space)
, the
Death Star (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_Star)
model from
Star Wars (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Wars)
, the
T-800 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminator_(character))
Terminator and one of the domes from the film
Silent Running (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silent_Running)
. Although the Science Fiction Museum as a permanent collection was de-installed in March 2011, a new exhibit named
Icons of Science Fiction
opened as a replacement in June 2012.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-kareiva-5)
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-CBS-6)
At this time the new Hall of Fame display was unveiled and the class of 2012 inducted.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof2012-7)
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof-new-8)
Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=3)
]
The Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame was founded in 1996 by the
Kansas City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri)
Science Fiction and Fantasy Society and the Center for the Study of Science Fiction (CSSF) at the
University of Kansas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Kansas)
(KU). The
chairmen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chairperson)
were Keith Stokes (1996–2001) and
Robin Wayne Bailey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robin_Wayne_Bailey)
(2002–2004). Only writers and editors were eligible for recognition and four were inducted annually, two deceased and two living. Each class of four was announced at
Kansas City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri)
's annual
science fiction convention (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science_fiction_convention)
,
ConQuesT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ConQuesT)
, and inducted at the Campbell Conference hosted by CSSF.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof-old-9)
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof-CSSF-10)
The Hall of Fame stopped inducting fantasy writers after 2004, when it became part of the Science Fiction Museum affiliated with the Museum of Pop Culture, under the name "Science Fiction Hall of Fame". Having inducted 36 writers in nine years, the organization began to recognize non-literary media in 2005.
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof-old-9)
It retained the quota of four new members and thus reduced the annual number of writers. The 2005 and 2006 press releases placed new members in "Literature", "Art", "Film, Television and Media", and "Open" categories, one for each category.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof2005-11)
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof2006-12)
In 2007 and 2008, the fourth inductee was placed in one of the three substantial categories.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof2007-13)
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-sfhof2008-14)
Nominations are submitted by the public, but the selections are made by "award-winning science fiction authors, artists, editors, publishers, and film professionals".
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-SFFhof-new-15)
MoPOP restored the original name online during June 2013 and announced five new members, one daily, beginning June 17, 2013. The first four were cited largely or wholly for science fiction works, however the final one was
J.R.R. Tolkien (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien)
, who was "hailed as the father of modern
fantasy literature (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy_literature)
".
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-SFFhof2013-16)

20th anniversary
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=5)
]

Cinema (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film)
,
Television (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television)
and Games), with two examples. A total of 20 additional inductees in both categories were also announced:

The X-Files (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_X-Files)
The class of 2023 brought the number of members to 109, which includes the 20 additional inductees added in 2016.
In November 2016, the museum changed its name from the Experience Music Project Museum to the Museum of Pop Culture, or MoPOP for short.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-31)
Architecture
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=6)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Skychurch2009.jpg)
The Sky Church
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ExperienceMusicProject.jpg)
An exterior view of the building
MoPOP is located on the campus of
Seattle Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center)
, adjacent to the
Space Needle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle)
and the
Seattle Center Monorail (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center_Monorail)
, which runs through the building. The structure itself was designed by
Frank Gehry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Gehry)
and resembles many of his firm's other works in its
sheet-metal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sheet_metal)
construction, such as
Guggenheim Museum Bilbao (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guggenheim_Museum_Bilbao)
,
Walt Disney Concert Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Disney_Concert_Hall)
, and
Gehry Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gehry_Tower)
. Much of the building material is exposed in the building's interior. The building contains 140,000 square feet (13,000 m
2
), with a 35,000-square-foot (3,300 m
2
)
footprint (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Footprint)
. The name of the museum's central Sky Church pays homage to
Jimi Hendrix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix)
. A concert venue capable of holding up to 800 guests, the last structural steel beam to be put in place bears the signatures of all construction workers who were on site on the day it was erected.
Hoffman Construction Company (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoffman_Construction_Company)
of
Portland, Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon)
, was the general contractor, while
Magnusson Klemencic Associates (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnusson_Klemencic_Associates)
of Seattle were the structural engineers for the project.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-32)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aerial_view_of_EMPSFM.jpg)
Design by
Frank Gehry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Gehry)
Even before
groundbreaking (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Groundbreaking)
, the
Seattle Weekly (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Weekly)
said the design could refer to "the often quoted comparison to a smashed
electric guitar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_guitar)
." Gehry himself had in fact made the comparison: "We started collecting pictures of
Stratocasters (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fender_Stratocaster)
, bringing in guitar bodies, drawing on those shapes in developing our ideas."
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-downey-33)
The architecture was greeted by Seattle residents with a mixture of acclaim for Gehry and derision for this particular edifice. British-born, Seattle-based writer
Jonathan Raban (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Raban)
remarked that "Frank Gehry has created some wonderful buildings, like the
Guggenheim Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guggenheim_Museum_Bilbao)
in Bilbao, but his Seattle effort, the Experience Music Project, is not one of them."
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-Raban-34)
New York Times (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times)
architecture critic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_criticism)
Herbert Muschamp (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Muschamp)
described it as "something that crawled out of the sea, rolled over, and died".
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-Barnett-35)
Forbes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes)
magazine called it one of the world's 10 ugliest buildings.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-Barnett-35)
Others describe it as a "blob"
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-cheek-36)
or call it "The
Hemorrhoids (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemorrhoid)
".
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-Raban-34)
Despite some critical reviews of the structure, the building has been called "a fitting backdrop for the world's largest collection of Jimi Hendrix
memorabilia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Souvenir)
."
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-fodor-37)
The building's exterior, which features a fusion of textures and colors including gold, silver, deep red, blue and a "shimmering purple haze",
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-enlow-38)
has been declared "an apt representation of the American rock experience."
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-skelton-39)
Finances
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=7)
]
The museum has had mixed financial success.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-cook-40)
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-AP-41)
In an effort to raise more funds, museum organizers used Allen's extensive art collection to create a 2006 exhibit at the museum entitled
DoubleTake: From Monet to Lichtenstein
.
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-farr-42)
The exhibit included
Roy Lichtenstein (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Lichtenstein)
's
The Kiss (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kiss_II)
(1962),
Pierre-Auguste Renoir (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir)
's
The Reader
(1877),
Vincent van Gogh (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh)
's
Orchard with Peach Trees in Blossom
(1888),
Pablo Picasso (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Picasso)
's
Four Bathers
(1921) and several works of art from
Claude Monet (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claude_Monet)
including one of the
Water Lilies (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_Lilies_(Monet_series))
paintings (1919) and
The Mula Palace
(1908).
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-43)
Since then the museum has organized numerous exhibitions focused more specifically on popular culture, such as
Sound and Vision: Artists Tell Their Stories
, which opened February 28, 2007. This brought together both music and science fiction in a single exhibit, and drew on the museum's extensive collection of
oral history (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oral_history)
recordings.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-oral-44)
The museum's recent exhibitions have ranged from
horror cinema (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horror_film)
, video games, and black leather jackets to fantasy film and literature.
Founders Award
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Museum_of_Pop_Culture&action=edit&section=8)
]
Since 2007, the Museum of Pop Culture's
Founders Award
has celebrated artists whose "noteworthy contributions continue to nurture the next generation of risk-takers". The annual benefit gala is key in funding the museum's educational programs, community engagement, and exhibitions.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-founders_award-45)
In 2020, due to the
COVID-19 pandemic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic)
, the gala had to be cancelled and for the first time ever, the event was made free to the public, streaming online on December 1, 2020, as MoPOP honored Seattle's own
Alice in Chains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_in_Chains)
.
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-aic-46)
The benefit streaming raised more than $600,000 for MoPOP in its first night. A compilation featuring highlights from the tribute was made available for streaming on
Amazon Music (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_Music)
.
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture#cite_note-47)

March 13, 1970
Pike Place Market
is a
public market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marketplaces#Types)
in
Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle)
, Washington, United States. It opened on August 17, 1907, and is one of the older continuously operated public
farmers' markets (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Farmers%27_market)
in the United States. Overlooking the
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
waterfront on
Puget Sound (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound)
, it serves as a place of business for many small farmers,
craftspeople (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craft)
and
merchants (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Merchant)
. It is named for its central street, Pike Place, which runs northwest from
Pike Street (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Street)
to Virginia Street on the western edge of
Downtown Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Seattle)
. Pike Place Market is Seattle's most popular tourist destination, with more than 20 million annual visitors.
The Market is built on the edge of a steep hill and consists of several lower levels located below the main level. Each features a variety of unique
shops (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retailing#Shops_and_stores)
such as
antique (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiques)
dealers,
comic book (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comic_book)
and collectible shops, small family-owned
restaurants (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Restaurant)
, and one of the oldest
head shops (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_shop)
in Seattle. The upper street level contains
fishmongers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fishmonger)
, fresh
produce (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Produce)
stands and craft stalls operating in the covered
arcades (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcade_(architecture))
. Local farmers and craftspeople sell year-round in the arcades from tables they rent from the Market on a daily basis, in accordance with the Market's mission and founding goal: allowing consumers to "Meet the Producer".
Pike Place Market is home to nearly 500 residents who live in eight different buildings throughout the Market. Most of these buildings have been low-income housing in the past; however, some of them no longer are, such as the Livingston Baker apartments. The Market is run by the
quasi-governmental (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_development_authority)
Pike Place Market Preservation and Development Authority (PDA).
Location and extent
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=1)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_Pike-Market_map.JPG)
"Pike-Market" neighborhood as represented in the City Clerk's
Seattle Neighborhood Atlas
. The heavy line on the map labeled "
Alaskan Way Viaduct (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaskan_Way_Viaduct)
" was part of
Washington State Route 99 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_State_Route_99)
(SR 99) prior to the viaduct's demolition in 2019. The unlabeled street inland from SR 99 as it passes the market is Western Avenue.
The Market is located roughly in the northwest corner of Seattle's
central business district (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown,_Seattle)
. To its north is
Belltown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belltown,_Seattle)
. To its southwest are the
central waterfront (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Waterfront,_Seattle)
and
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
. Boundaries are diagonal to the compass since the street grid is roughly parallel to the Elliott Bay shoreline.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Seattle_Clerk_Office_Map-2)
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-About_Seattle_Clerk_Office_Map-3)
[4] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-4)
As is common with Seattle neighborhoods and districts,
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-About_Seattle_Clerk_Office_Map-3)
different people and organizations draw different boundaries for the market. The City Clerk's Neighborhood Map Atlas gives one of the more expansive definitions, defining a "Pike-Market" neighborhood extending from Union Street northwest to Virginia Street and from the waterfront northeast to Second Avenue.
[2] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Seattle_Clerk_Office_Map-2)
Despite coming from the City Clerk's office, this definition has no special official status.
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-About_Seattle_Clerk_Office_Map-3)
The smaller "Pike Place Public Market Historic District" listed on the U.S.
National Register of Historic Places (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places)
is bounded roughly by First Avenue, Virginia Street, Western Avenue, and a building wall about halfway between Union and Pike Streets, running parallel to those streets.
[5] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-5)
In a middle ground between those two definitions, the Seattle Department of Neighborhoods' official 7-acre (28,000 m
2
) "Pike Place Market Historical District"
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-hist-dist-6)
includes the federally recognized Pike Place Public Market Historic District plus a slightly smaller piece of land between Western Avenue and
Washington State Route 99 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_State_Route_99)
, on the side of the market toward Elliott Bay.
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-7)
To some extent, these different definitions of the market district result from struggles between preservationists and developers. For example, the
National Historic Preservation Act of 1966 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Historic_Preservation_Act_of_1966)
created the Washington Advisory Council on Historic Preservation.
Victor Steinbrueck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck)
, at one point in the late 1960s, convinced the Advisory Council to recommend designating 17 acres (69,000 m
2
) as a historical district. Pressure by developers and the "Seattle establishment" soon got that reduced to a tenth of that area.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-9)
The present-day historic district designations lie between these extremes.
Part of the market sits on what was originally
mudflats (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mudflats)
below the bluffs west of Pike Place. In the late 19th century, West Street (now Western Avenue, angling away from Pike Place) was already a through street running more or less parallel to the shore. Railroad Avenue (now Alaskan Way) was built farther out on pilings; it was not filled in until the 1930s. Nearby piers with warehouses for convenient
stevedoring (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stevedore)
had already been completed by 1905, two years before the market opened.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-10)
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-11)
History
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=2)
]
Main article:
History of Pike Place Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Pike_Place_Market)
The market was created in 1907 when
Seattle City Council (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_City_Council)
member
Thomas P. Revelle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_P._Revelle)
took advantage of an 1896 ordinance that allowed the city to designate tracts of land as public markets
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-12)
and designated a portion of the area of Western Avenue above the
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
tideflats off Pike Street and First Avenue.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-13)
The market was opened August 17, 1907, by City Council President
Charles Hiram Burnett (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Hiram_Burnett_Sr.)
Jr.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-official-web-history-14)
The first building at the Market, the Main Arcade, opened November 30, 1907.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-15)
Demand for stalls grew and by 1911 the number of available stalls had doubled. The west side of the stall lines were soon covered in an overhead canopy and roofing, becoming known as the "dry row".
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-16)
In 1916 the market expanded into the
Economy Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_Market)
.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-17)
Throughout the early 1920s, the north side of the
Corner Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corner_Market)
became known as the
Sanitary Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanitary_Market)
and the area developed into a social scene.
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-:0-18)
A new ordinance forbidding farmers' stalls to be placed in the street resulted in proposals to move the market, but in 1921 the City Council voted to retain the existing location and work on expanding in place.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Shorett_2007_50-19)
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-20)
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-21)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_marketplace.jpg)
An assortment of fruits available for sale
In 1963, a proposal was floated to demolish Pike Place Market and replace it with
Pike Plaza
, which met community opposition, including help from
Betty Bowen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betty_Bowen)
,
Victor Steinbrueck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck)
, Ibsen Nelsen, and others from the board of Friends of the Market.
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-22)
An
initiative (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Popular_initiative)
was passed on November 2, 1971, that created a
historic preservation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historic_preservation)
zone and returned the Market to public hands.
In the 1980s, a nonprofit group, the Pike Place Market Foundation, was established by the PDA to raise funds and administer the Market's free clinic, senior center, low-income housing, and childcare center.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
The 1983 Hildt Amendment or Hildt Agreement (named after City Council member Michael Hildt) struck a balance between farmers and craftspeople in the daystalls which set a precedent for allocation of daystalls.
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Worth-23)
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-24)
In 1998, the PDA decided to end the Hildt Agreement;
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-iv-25)
a new agreement, the Licata-Hildt agreement, was adopted in February 1999.
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-26)
In 2008, Seattle voters approved a six-year property-tax levy
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-27)
to fund critical repairs and improvements, which were completed in 2012.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-28)
Operation
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=3)
]
Organizations
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=4)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sisio%27s_Fruit_%26_Produce_at_Pike_Place_Market_(2015).jpg)
Fresh vegetables at the market
The Pike Place Market is overseen by the Pike Place Market Preservation & Development Authority (PDA), a
public development authority (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_development_authority)
established under Washington State law. It is overseen by a 12-member volunteer council. Its members serve four-year terms. Four members are appointed by mayor, four by the current council, and four by the Pike Place Market Constituency. The Market PDA sets the policies by which the Pike Place Market is managed and hires an executive director to carry out those policies.
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-29)
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_official-30)
Established in 1973, the PDA manages 80% of the properties in the city-recognized Market Historical District. Its founding law—the Market Charter—requires it to preserve, rehabilitate and protect the Market's buildings; increase opportunities for farm and food retailing in the Market; incubate and support small and marginal businesses; and provide services for low-income people. PDA revenues derive from the Market's tenants through rent, utilities, and other property management activities.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_official-30)
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_merchant-31)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PikePlaceMarket.jpg)
Pike Place Market at dawn, with the
Pike Place Fish Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Fish_Market)
getting ready for the day's trade
The same 1973 charter that established the PDA also established the Pike Place Market Constituency. The Constituency elects one member to the PDA Council each year. Anyone 16 years of age or older who lives in Washington State can become a member of the Constituency by paying $1 yearly dues.
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_official-30)
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_merchant-31)
Operating independently of the PDA, the Market Historical Commission (established by the 1971 initiative to preserve the Market) has the specific mandate to preserve the Market's physical and social character as "the soul of Seattle."
[6] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-hist-dist-6)
The commission must approve any substantive change in the use or design of buildings and signage in the Historical District, even when these actions are taken by the PDA itself. Members of the 12-member commission are appointed to three-year terms by the mayor. At any time, the commission consists of two members each from the Friends of the Market, Inc.,
Allied Arts of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allied_Arts_of_Seattle)
, Inc., and the Seattle chapter of the
American Institute of Architects (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects)
; two owners of property within the district; two Market merchants, and two district residents. They meet 22 times a year. The Seattle Department of Neighborhoods provides them with a staff person, and the city's Department of Design, Construction and Land Use (DCLU) can enforce their decisions.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-5-32)
Another key organization in the affairs of the Market is the Pike Place Merchants Association.
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-merchants-mission-33)
Officially incorporated in 1973,
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-22-34)
it traces its history back to the Farm Association established in the 1920s. The association connects market vendors to legal, accounting, bookkeeping, business insurance, and health insurance services
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-merchants-mission-33)
and provides free online advertising for its members. It also represents its members and attempts to advance their interests and opinions. All PDA tenants are required to be members; daystall vendors also have the option to join.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-22-34)
Since 1974, the association has published the monthly
Pike Place Market News
, which promotes the Market and its neighborhood.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Market_organizations_merchant-31)
For over three decades, the association sponsored a
Memorial Day (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Day)
fair at the market; financial difficulties caused cancellation of the fair in 2004.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-35)
A separate Daystall Tenants Association (DTA) formed in the late 1980s to represent the specific interests of daystall vendors. The DTA formed in response to proposed increases in daystall rental rates. Most members pay a $2 annual membership fee; the fee is optional. The DTA meets on the Desimone Bridge in the Market at least once each quarter. Similarly, the United Farmers Coalition (UFC) formed in 1998 to represent daystall farmers who sell produce, flower, and processed food; the UFC represents only these food vendors, as against craft vendors.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-22-34)
The Pike Market Performers' Guild, founded 2001, represents Market street performers.
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-36)
Among its members are
Artis the Spoonman (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artis_the_Spoonman)
and
Jim Page (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jim_Page_(singer))
.
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-37)
Friends of the Market, which spun out of Allied Arts in 1964 and over the next seven years spearheaded the activist work that saved the Market
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-38)
is no longer a driving force in the Market. Still, as noted above, they have two seats on the Historical Commission. They also give tours of the Market.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-39)
The Market Foundation (established 1982) was founded to support the Market's services for low-income people. The foundation now also supports heritage programs, improvements and repairs to historic buildings, and programs that assist the Market's farmers.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Foundation-40)
Conflicts
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=5)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pike_Place_Market_-_apples_for_sale.jpg)
Farmer selling apples in a daystall
The PDA is a public trustee charged with many potentially conflicting goals. Its charter mandates it to "ensure that the traditional character of the Public Market is preserved." It is specifically mandated to
...
afford... a continuing opportunity for Public Market farmers, merchants, residents, shoppers, and visitors to carry on their tradition and market activities...  upgrad[e] structures and public amenities... initiate programs to expand food retailing in the Market Historical District, especially the sale of local farm produce; to preserve and expand the residential community, especially for low-income people; to promote the survival and predominance of small shops, marginal businesses, thrift shops, arts and crafts, and other enterprises, activities, and services which are essential to the functioning of the Public Market
.
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-41)
The City Auditor's office has stated that there is an "inherent conflict... between the PDA's need to operate the Market as a successful business entity and its Charter obligation to support small owner-operated tenant businesses."
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-42)
As early as 1974, a Seattle Department of Community Development study noted space conflicts between farmers and craft vendors.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-12-43)
Conflicts can be exacerbated because the stakeholders with conflicting needs are not talking to one another. Quoting the same City Auditor's report:
Most Market tenants do not routinely communicate with tenants in other areas of the Market. As a result, they sometimes criticize the PDA for not implementing suggestions they believe would work for them and their close neighbors—e.g., closing all or part of Pike Place to auto traffic—not realizing that their "solutions" would create problems for tenants in other parts of the Market. Then they conclude that the PDA is not taking their comments and suggestions seriously
.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-44)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PikePlaceMarket2006.jpg)
A fishmonger's stall in the Main Arcade. Open-fronted, but rented on a lease, not as a daystall.
Language barriers also play a role. For example, most of the flower vendors in the Market are
Hmong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hmong_people)
; during the difficult negotiations in 1999 over replacing the Hildt Agreement, many were apparently under a misimpression that the proposed agreement would have halved the vending space they received for a day's rent; in fact, this was unchanged.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-45)
Further, the farmers who were the Market's original
raison d'etre
do not necessarily do well when the Market becomes more of a tourist attraction than venue for shopping for produce and groceries.
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Seattle_Times_May_27,_2008-46)
"Craft vendors, antique and curio merchants, and booksellers…" wrote the City Auditor's office, "derive much of their business from tourists; fresh food vendors do not."
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-47)
Conversely, farmers have far more selling opportunities outside the Market than in the early and mid-20th century. As late as 1990, there were about ten farmers markets in Washington. By 1999 there were more than sixty. Most are seasonal weekend markets without most of the Pike Place Market's amenities, but they are not swarmed with tourists, parking is free or inexpensive and relatively plentiful, and food is the main focus of those markets, not crafts or flowers.
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-48)
As a result, increasingly Pike Place Market daystalls are devoted to flowers and crafts rather than edible produce. "The Market," wrote the City Auditor's office,
...
can be "lost" in either of two ways: It can stray from its traditional character or it can fail financially as a business entity. If the Market is to survive and thrive as a business entity in the face of increasing competition from other farmers' markets, modern full-service grocery stores, and retail shopping destinations in Seattle's Central Business District, the PDA must strike a balance between the Market's original old-world market character and modern business practices
.
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-49)
Policies
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=6)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pike_Place_Market_-_Chop_carver.jpg)
Chinese
seal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seal_(East_Asia))
(chop) carver at an outdoor craft daystall on Pike Place just south of Virginia Street
The Market's "Meet the Producer" mandate now includes craftspeople as well as farmers. Both can rent daystalls. Farmers take historic precedence, but the PDA "acknowledges the rightful and permanent position of handmade arts and crafts as an integral use of the Market's Daystalls" and their rules seek to encourage a lively mix.
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-3-50)
Some grandfathered vendors are allowed to sell merchandise not of their own making on essentially the same terms as craftspeople.
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-4-51)
Currently, there are rules to make sure that new crafts vendors demonstrate themselves to be skilled craftspeople making their own wares with minimal use of assistants.
[52] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-52)
A standard Farm Table consists of two adjacent daystalls; a standard Craft Table is a single daystall. Daystalls are between 4 feet (1.2 m) and 5.5 feet (1.7 m) wide. Craftspeople have priority on the Desimone Bridge, the west side of the Market arcade north of the Desimone Bridge and the outdoor slabs between the arcade and Virginia Street; farmers have priority everywhere else. If farmers do not fill their priority tables, craftspeople may rent those, and
vice versa
.
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-4-51)
Priority is further set by separate seniority lists, one for farmers and one for craftspeople.
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-6-53)
For farmers, other factors besides seniority come into play, mainly how often the person sells at the Market. Farmers can pass permits through their family.
[54] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-54)
The rules for joint and family crafts businesses are far more complex.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-55)
While farmers and craftspeople may make some use of agents to sell on their behalf (including vendors functioning on different days as one another's agents), in order to maintain their seniority farmers must be physically present one day a week and craftspeople two days a week. To sell on a Saturday, vendors must sell at the Market a minimum of two weekdays of the preceding week. There are also allowances for taking vacations and sabbaticals without losing one's seniority. Senior Crafts Permit Holders—craftspeople who have sold in the Market for 30 years or more—need only rent (and use) a daystall once a week to maintain their seniority.
[56] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-56)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:13_Pike_Place_Market_flower_vendor_displays.jpg)
Flowers for sale in Main Arcade daystalls
The definition of permitted farm products includes (among other items) produce, flowers, eggs, cultivated mushrooms, meat, cultured shellfish, and dairy products. There is also a broader category of supplemental farm products such as wild-harvested berries and mushrooms, non-edible bee products, or holiday wreaths. These may be sold in conjunction with permitted farm products, but there are strict limitations to prevent these from becoming anyone's primary products. Rules vary significantly at different times of year.
[57] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-57)
Farmers, craftspeople, and performers all must pay for an annual permit. As of 2008, the fee is $35 for farmers and craftspeople, $30 for performers. Craftspeople who vend off season—January through March—pay an additional $35 for a separate permit. For performers, this annual fee is their only fee. Farmers and craftspeople pay day rent for any daystalls they use. Depending on the season and the day of the week, a daystall may rent for anywhere from $5.85 for a stall on a Monday-Thursday off season to $32.85 on a Sunday in peak season. There are also separate rents for lockers and coolers.
[58] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-7-58)
Compared to farmers and craftspeople, performers have a lesser role in the Market, but still one formally recognized by the PDA. "The PDA's mission with regard to performers is to maintain locations within the Market where performing artists may entertain Market shoppers in a fashion consistent with and complimentary [
sic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sic)
] to the needs of the Market's commercial business activities and Market residents.
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-3-50)
Performers may receive donations and may display their recordings for sale, but prohibited from active solicitation of donations and from active sale of "any product associated with the performance".
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-regs-6-53)
In keeping with their lack of day fees, individual performers are not assigned specific places and times to perform. There are only positions in a (virtual) line for each marked, sanctioned performance location. Queuing runs on an honor system. Each performance is limited to one hour if any other licensed performer is waiting for the spot. Electronic amplification is not allowed, nor are brass instruments or drums. Certain performance locations are further limited to "quiet" performances where (for example) even hand-clap percussion is not allowed.
[59] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-59)
Although they do not have the same strict requirements as for daystalls, most commercial Market merchants are owner-operated businesses.
[60] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-42-60)
In the 1970s, when the Market was undergoing extensive rehabilitation and the future of the Market was somewhat unstable, the PDA consolidated its merchant base by giving merchant tenants very favorable leases, with longer terms and lower rates than were available elsewhere in Downtown Seattle. This policy was part of the reason that the PDA ran into the financial difficulties that led to its dealings with the Urban Group. The PDA now gives below-market rates only to start-up businesses, businesses or organizations designed to serve low and moderate income persons, and to "the Market's unique character-defining businesses."
[61] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-61)
The latter include produce, fish, and meat businesses.
[62] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-62)
The PDA often will not renew multi-year leases for businesses with poor sales performance or other problems, but typically will allow them to remain indefinitely on a month-to-month basis.
[63] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-63)
About once a year, the PDA has occasion to refuse to renew when a merchant's lease ends.
[60] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-42-60)
Housing and social services
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=7)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Balloon_man_Pike_Place_Market_Seattle_Washington.JPG)
Thomas the Balloon Man, longtime vendor
The Market is also a significant provider of low-income housing and social services. The Market Foundation supports the Pike Market Medical Clinic, Pike Market Senior Center, Downtown Food Bank, and Pike Market Childcare and Preschool (all within the Market), as well as
low-income housing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-income_housing)
in and near the Market.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Foundation-40)
They provide Market Fresh coupons to their low-income tenants, redeemable for Market produce, and implement the FoodLink program that distributes unsold Market produce to other Seattle
food banks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_bank)
and meal programs.
[64] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Jones-6-64)
The money placed in the Market's
giant piggybank (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#Rachel_and_Pigs_on_Parade)
goes to this foundation, as do the funds raised by several annual or intermittent fundraisers, including
Pigs on Parade (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#Rachel_and_Pigs_on_Parade)
.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Foundation-40)
About 500 people live in the market. Approximately 90% are low-income seniors with subsidized rents. Their average income is only $11,095 a year.
[65] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-65)
Among the low-income units in the Market are 41 in the LaSalle Hotel, 51 in Market House, 44 in the Stewart House and 96 in the Livingston-Baker.
[66] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-66)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_-_Landes_Block_01.jpg)
Landes Block, also known as the Hotel Livingston or the Livingston-Baker Apartments. The Pike Market Medical Clinic is in the lower portion of this building, facing onto
Post Alley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post_Alley)
. Part of the Pike and Virginia Building can be seen at right.
The Pike Market Medical Clinic provides primary care and ancillary services to 3,600 patients. Most of these are either elderly,
HIV (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HIV)
-positive, or working poor. One third homeless, 30% are physically disabled, and 60% have severe mental illness and/or chemical addiction. The clinic provides basic medical care, subsidized prescriptions, lab work, mental health counseling, drug and alcohol counseling, connections to other community services, and sometimes even assistance in finding housing.
[67] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-67)
Approximately 900 people use the Market's senior center. Services include hot lunches for low-income seniors, help in finding housing and jobs, and a variety of classes ranging from physical fitness and health to language, geography, art, and computer training.
[68] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-68)
The Downtown Food Bank, located in the Public Market Parking Garage on Western Avenue provides groceries to approximately 1,000 people a week. About 265 bags of groceries are delivered weekly to homebound downtown residents. About 160 families receive infant milk, baby food and diapers.
[69] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-69)
The child care and preschool serves 90–100 families with children ages 2–5 each year. 84% of families with children attending are low-income and receive tuition assistance. Besides its educational aspects, the school provides these children with breakfast, lunch, and afternoon snacks and has a full-time, onsite child and family support professional to identify resources children their families might need and to link them to those resources.
[70] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-70)
Attractions
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=8)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pike_Place_Market_-_Tenzing_Momo_02.jpg)
Herbal apothecary
Tenzing Momo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tenzing_Momo)
One of the Market's major attractions is
Pike Place Fish Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Fish_Market)
, where employees throw three-foot salmon and other fish to each other rather than passing them by hand. When a customer orders a fish, an employee at the Fish Market's ice-covered fish table picks up the fish and hurls it over the countertop, where another employee catches it and preps it for sale.
[71] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-71)
The first
Starbucks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starbucks)
store, founded in 1971, was originally located at 2000 Western Avenue.
[72] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Allison-Starbucks-72)
In 1977 it moved one block away to 1912 Pike Place where it has been in continuous operation ever since.  The store was opened by three partners:
Jerry Baldwin (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerry_Baldwin)
,
Zev Siegl (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zev_Siegl)
and
Gordon Bowker (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gordon_Bowker)
. They were inspired by
Alfred Peet (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_Peet)
of
Peet's Coffee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peet%27s_Coffee)
to open the store and sell high-quality coffee beans and coffee making equipment and accessories.
[73] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-73)
The sign outside this branch, unlike others, features the original logo – a bare-breasted
siren (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Siren_(mythology))
that was modeled after a 15th-century Norse woodcut.
[74] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-74)
[75] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-75)
It also features a pig statue called "Pork'n Beans," purchased in the 2001 Pigs on Parade fundraiser.
[76] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-76)
Starbucks now owns the
Seattle's Best Coffee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle%27s_Best_Coffee)
(SBC) brand, which traces its history back to Stewart Brothers' Coffee, which arrived in the Market several months before Starbucks was founded.
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-77)
On March 8, 2011, the store was the site of a
NASDAQ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASDAQ)
opening bell ringing as Starbucks kicked off its 40th anniversary.
[78] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-78)
After more than 30 years in the Market, the herbal apothecary
Tenzing Momo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tenzing_Momo)
has become an institution both for obtaining herbs and advice on their use. Founded in 1977, the name (which is
Tibetan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Tibetan)
) means "divine dumpling".
[79] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-79)
[80] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-80)
[81] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-81)
Nearby, Market Spice (founded 1911) sells slightly less exotic herbal substances.
[82] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-82)
[83] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-83)
The Market Heritage Center at 1531 Western Avenue is a small museum about the history of the Market.
[84] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-84)
Pike Place Market is Seattle's most popular tourist destination and among the most visited tourist attractions in the world.
[85] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-85)
In 2023, the market had 20.9
million total visitors and $177
million in commercial sales.
[86] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-86)
The name "Pike's Place" is commonly used by non-Seattleites despite being grammatically incorrect, as the market is not named for a particular person.
[87] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-87)
Rachel and Pigs on Parade
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=9)

[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pike_Place_Piggy_2008.JPG)
The Pike Place Market's unofficial bronze mascot, Rachel
Pike Place Market's unofficial mascot,
Rachel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rachel_(Gerber))
, a
bronze (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bronze)
cast
piggy bank (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piggy_bank)
that weighs 550 pounds (250 kg), has been located since 1986 at the corner of Pike Place under the "Public Market Center" sign. Rachel was designed by local artist Georgia Gerber and modeled after a pig (also named Rachel) that lived on
Whidbey Island (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whidbey_Island)
and was the 1977
Island County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Island_County)
prize-winner. Rachel receives roughly US$6,000–$9,000 annually in just about every type of world currency, which is collected by the Market Foundation to fund the Market's social services.
[88] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-porcine-88)
[89] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-89)
Rachel provided the theme for the Pigs on Parade fundraiser that was first held in 2001 and was one of several events in various cities modeled on a similar 1998 event in
Zurich (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zurich)
; the Zurich event centered on cows and was the first of what have come to be known as
CowParades (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CowParade)
.
[90] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-90)
[91] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-91)
A similar Pigs On Parade fundraiser was held in 2007 on the occasion of the Market centennial, which happened to coincide with the
Chinese zodiac (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_zodiac)
Year of the Pig (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pig_(zodiac))
.
[92] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-92)
[93] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-93)

spoons (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoon_(musical_instrument))

steel guitarist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steel_guitar)
Baby Gramps (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baby_Gramps)
;
[94] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-94)
Johnny Hahn, who routinely hauls around a 64-key

[95] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-95)

;
[96] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-96)
klezmer influenced musicians the Bus Tunnel Bandits;
hoop busker (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoop_busker)
musician Emery Carl, chairman of the Market's Performer's Guild;
[97] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-97)
blind
autoharpist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoharp)

[98] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-98)
Kirsten "Mother Zosima" Anderberg, who for many years sang feminist and other political songs while dressed in a nun's habit;
[99] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-99)
[100] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-100)
a cappella (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_cappella)
gospel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gospel_music)

[101] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-101)
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-busker-fest-5-102)
the
old-timey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_time_music)
Tallboys;
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-busker-fest-5-102)
[103] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-103)
Johnny Cash sound-alike
Vince Mira (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vince_Mira)
;
[104] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-104)
jazz-tinged players Amber Tide (Thaddeus Spae and his late wife Sandahbeth);
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-busker-fest-5-102)
[105] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-105)
alternative-jazz-pop singer-songwriter
Alyse Black (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alyse_Black)
, and the late folksinger Jim Hinde, a

veteran.
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-busker-fest-5-102)
[106] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-106)
Jump blues (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jump_blues)
musician
PK Dwyer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PK_Dwyer)
is credited with forming the first-ever street band to busk at the Market. He formed that band, Felix & the Freelicks, shortly after he arrived in the Pacific Northwest in 1971. The band evolved into various other alignments, including (successively) the Dynamic Logs, the Jitters, Throbbing Gems, the Royal Famille du Caniveaux / Gutter People of Paris, all of whom played at the Market.
[107] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-107)
Some of these alignments also included Ron Bailey;
[108] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-108)
the Dynamic Logs included
Orville Johnson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orville_Johnson)
as well.
[109] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-109)
The band, Morrison Boomer, is a more recent staple and known to record live music at the market.
