Dining and drinking
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=11)
]
See also:
List of restaurants in Pike Place Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_restaurants_in_Pike_Place_Market)
The Pike Place Market offers numerous other eating and drinking options. The once endemic workingmen's and sailors' taverns are gone; at roughly opposite corners of the Market, the Virginia Inn (founded as Virginia Bar, approximately 1908; operated as a
cardroom (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardroom)
during
Prohibition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prohibition)
, then Virginia Inn; passed into current management 1980 and slowly gentrified) and Place Pigalle (originally Lotus Inn, name dates from 1950s, remodeled 1982) retain their names, but both have gone upmarket.
[111] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Pigalle-hist-111)
[112] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-112)
[113] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Enduring-113)
The Athenian Inn in the Main Market traces its history back to a 1909 bakery and is a relatively ungentrified bar and restaurant.
[114] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-114)
Three Girls Bakery (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Girls_Bakery)
dates back to 1912 and may have been the first Seattle business started by women. While it is not in its original
Corner Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corner_Market)
location, no longer bakes on premises, and its current owner Jack Levy is a man, it still sells a vast variety of baked goods, does a brisk business in takeaway sandwiches, and has an old-style lunch counter.
[115] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-115)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Post_Alley_Pike_Place_Market_Seattle_Washington_June_2010.JPG)
View along
Post Alley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post_Alley)
in the Market
The Pink Door (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pink_Door)
(founded 1981), entered by a nearly unmarked door on upper
Post Alley (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Post_Alley)
, is a favorite first-date restaurant, with solid Italian food, a fantasia of a dining room, a bar that sometimes features live jazz, and an outdoor deck overlooking Elliott Bay.
[113] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Enduring-113)
[116] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-116)
[117] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-117)
Another restaurant combining Italian food and romantic ambience is the Il Bistro, located below grade in the
Economy Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_Market)
, off the winding cobblestones of Lower Post Alley. When it was founded in 1977 it was played an important role in the rise of fine dining in Seattle.
[118] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-118)
Other longstanding Market restaurants and bars include Lowell's (founded 1957), an old Main Market standby self-described as "almost classy";
[119] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-119)
French bistro Maximilien, founded in 1975 by François Kissel, owned since 1997 by host Axel Macé and chef Eric Francy, and highly praised by
Julia Child (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julia_Child)
;
[120] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-120)
[121] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-121)
[122] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-122)
and the
Copacabana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copacabana_Restaurant)
(founded 1964), Seattle's only
Bolivian (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivian_cuisine)
restaurant, upstairs in the
Triangle Building (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangle_Building_(Seattle))
with a balcony overlooking Pike Place.
[113] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Enduring-113)
People
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=12)
]
Frank Goodwin and his brothers developed most of the core Market buildings. He was largely responsible for the decision to keep ornamentation to a minimum, in order to keep the emphasis on the products rather than the institution and in order not to scare off people looking for good prices on their produce. Upon his retirement in 1925, his nephew Arthur Goodwin took over most of the Market ownership, selling some shares to people outside of the family.
[123] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Evans_1991_p=4–6-123)
Giuseppe Desimone was born about 40 miles (64 km) east of
Naples (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naples)
, Italy.
[124] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-124)
He arrived in America from Italy as a stowaway, but soon became a successful farmer with land in
South Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Park,_Seattle)
,
Tukwila (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tukwila,_Washington)
and the
Kent (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kent,_Washington)
Valley along the
Green River (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_River_(Duwamish_River))
. A longtime Market vendor, Desimone was one of those who bought shares in the Market in 1925 and eventually became its owner by slowly buying out Arthur Goodwin. He was president of the Market until his death in 1946. Outside of the Market, he is credited with keeping
Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing)
in the Seattle area in 1936 by selling them a large tract of land for a nominal fee.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[125] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Desimone-125)
His son Richard Desimone succeeded him as president of the market and served in that position until 1974. He kept the Market alive in dark times for farmers' markets, doing nearly all business on handshake deals rather than through formal leases. He later served on the Market Historical Commission.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[125] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Desimone-125)
Victor Steinbrueck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck)
was the leading architect-activist in defining the Pike Market neighborhood, and artist
Mark Tobey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mark_Tobey)
in visualizing and recording, in developing his "Northwest Mystic" style of the internationally recognized Northwest School of art. Internationally recognized in the 1940s, Tobey explored the neighborhood with his art in the 1950s and early 1960s,
[126] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-126)
[127] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-127)
as the area was being increasingly characterized by the Seattle Establishment as overdue for
urban renewal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_renewal)
, particularly replacement with a parking garage, high-rise housing and modern, upscale retail.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
People of city neighborhoods and citizen preservation activists struggled through the 1960s, culminating in 1971 with 2 to 1 passage of a citizen initiative for protection and citizen oversight of the core Pike Place Market that has since largely protected the neighborhood.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[128] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Lange-1999-128)
[129] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Wilma-1999-129)
For many years, Sol "The Cod Father" Amon of Pure Food Fish has been the longest-tenured vendor at Pike Place Market. His father, Jack Amon, began selling fish in the Market in 1911 as a partner in the Philadelphia Fish Market. From about 1920 to 1935, he owned and operated the American Fish Company. In 1951 he bought the Pure Food Fish Company (founded 1917–1918), which Sol Amon largely took over in 1956. Sol had worked in the Market since 1947 and has been sole proprietor of Pure Food Fish since his father's death in 1966. He can often be seen outside his stall chatting with visitors and helping them choose their fish, including a brisk tourist trade in salmon packed to travel. The
Seattle City Council (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_City_Council)
honored him in 2006 on the 50th anniversary of his taking over the business: they named him "King of the Market" and permanently designated April 11 as Sol Amon Day. Amon is a longtime major supporter of the Market Foundation. On the first Sol Amon Day in 2006, Amon donated all of the day's profits from Pure Food Fish to the foundation.
[130] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-130)
[131] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-131)
[132] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-132)
[123] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Evans_1991_p=4–6-123)
Walter DeMarsh of Mobeta Shoes has made custom shoes for people with foot disfigurements and deformities since 1979.
[133] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Kornelis-133)
Buildings
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=13)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pike_Place_Market_from_West_Edge_Tower.jpg)
Aerial view of Pike Place Market from the east
Few of the historic buildings in the Pike-Market neighborhood (and none of the Market buildings as such) are individually designated as landmarks or registered as historic places. Buildings included in the federally and locally designated historic districts gain most of the benefits that would accrue from individual designation, so there is little reason to go through the difficult process of obtaining separate designation.
Market buildings
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=14)
]
The Market began on a boardwalk adjacent to the 3-story Leland Hotel
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
(1900, architect unknown). The Leland was incorporated in 1907 by engineer John Goodwin into the Main Arcade. In 1914–1915 he and architect Andrew Willatsen extended this complex further into the Fairley Building, which includes Lowell's, the Athenian, and the "Down Under". The complex was rehabilitated in 1977 by George Bartholick. As of 2008, the upper two stories of the Leland continue to be housing.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[134] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-134)
[135] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-135)
Together, all of these constitute today's Main Market.
The two-story
Triangle Building (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangle_Building_(Seattle))
(Thompson & Thompson, 1908; rehabilitation by
Fred Bassetti & Co. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassetti_Architects)
, 1977) originally housed the South Park Poultry Company. The 1977 rehabilitation joined it with the adjacent 3-story
Silver Oakum Building (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silver_Oakum_Building)
(unknown, 1910; Bassetti, 1977).
[136] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-136)
The Outlook Hotel (now LaSalle Hotel; architect unknown; rehabilitation by Bartholick, 1977) also dates from 1908. A legitimate seaman's and workingman's hotel until 1942, its
Japanese American (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_American)
operators Rosuke and T.K. Kodama were forcibly
interned (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_American_internment)
during World War II. Nellie Curtis took it over, changed the name, and ran it as a brothel into the 1950s. Since 1977 the building has been joined to the adjacent Cliff House (c. 1901), and largely devoted to low-income housing. Shops and the Market PDA office are on the ground floor.
[111] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Pigalle-hist-111)
[137] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-137)
Its roof provides outdoor seating for the restaurant Maximilien.
[138] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-138)
The
Sanitary Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanitary_Market)
(Daniel Huntington, 1910; reconstructed 1942, McClelland and Jones; rehabilitated and extended 1981,
Bassetti Norton Metler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassetti_Architects)
) reputedly was so named for its innovation at the time, that no horses were allowed inside. A fire on December 15, 1941, severely damaged the building, which was reconstructed as a 2-story building with rooftop parking. Nearly four decades later the parking lot was eliminated, replaced by two floors of residences.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-1999-8)
[139] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Elenga_2007_p=153-139)
[140] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-140)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_-_Place_Pigalle_01.jpg)
Place Pigalle sits atop the LaSalle Hotel.
The North Arcade (1911 and 1922, John Goodwin; rehabilitation by Bartholick, 1977) constituted a major northward extension of the Main Market, extending it 1,200 feet (370 m) to the northwest and adding 160 covered stalls.
[141] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-141)
The 3-story
Corner Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corner_Market)
building (Harlan Thomas & Clyde Grainger 1912; rehabilitation by Karlis Rekevics, 1975) sits on the right as one enters the Market along Pike Street. In its early years it included daystalls, and the businesses facing onto First Avenue were open-fronted. The Three Girls Bakery, the first known business in the Corner Market, is now located in the adjacent Sanitary Market. The basement was home to Patti Summers' jazz club for over two decades before becoming Can Can in 2006; the building is also home to
anarchist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anarchism)
bookstore
Left Bank Books (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infoshop)
, as well as numerous other businesses.
[139] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Elenga_2007_p=153-139)
[142] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-142)
[143] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-143)
Across Pike Street from the Corner Market is the
Economy Market (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_Market)
(unknown, 1900, as Bartell Building; remodeled by John Goodwin & Andrew Willatsen 1916; rehabilitation by Bartholick, 1978). The 1978 rehabilitation occurred in conjunction with the construction of the adjacent South Arcade
[144] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-144)
at the corner of First Avenue and Union Street (Olsen / Walker, 1985). The South Arcade lies outside of the protected historic Market areas. It includes
condominium (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condominium_(living_space))
apartments, but also the Pike Pub & Brewery and several other retail businesses of a similar character to those within the Market boundaries. Its owner, Harbor Properties, describes it as "adjacent to" the Market.
[145] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-145)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:06_Pike_Place_Market_Desimone_bridge_with_vendors_inside_on_Western_Avenue_facing_north.jpg)
The Joe Desimone Bridge once connected the North Arcade to the now-demolished Municipal Market Building. It now contains craft-priority daystalls.
The Joe Desimone Bridge across Western Avenue originally connected the North Arcade to the Municipal Market Building (unknown, 1922 or 1924; demolished after a 1974 fire). The bridge is now enclosed on three sides (1985, James Cutler Architects) and used for craft-priority daystalls.
[146] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-146)
[147] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-147)
Other old buildings in the Market include the Champion Building (unknown, 1928; rehabilitation by the Champion/Turner Partnership 1977), originally a garage for the Dollar Cab Company, then a meat packing company, now ground floor retail with offices above; the Soames-Dunn Building (unknown, 1918; rehabilitation by Arne Bystrom 1976), once home to Dunn's Seeds and Soames Paper Company (who supplied paper bags to farmers selling in the Market), now retail, including the
"original" Starbucks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_Starbucks)
; Stewart House Hotel (unknown, 1902–1911; rehabilitation by Ibsen Nelson & Associates, 1982), a former workingmen's hotel, now retail and low-income housing; Seattle Garden Center (W. C. Geary, 1908;
Art Deco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_Deco)
details added 1930s; rehabilitation and addition, Arne Bystrom 1976) was once the Gem Egg Market and now houses
Sur La Table (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sur_La_Table)
; and the Fix-Madore Building (1916, unknown; rehabilitation by Bumgardner Partnership 1979), now an office and retail building on the west side of Western Avenue, connected to the Main Market by a footbridge.
[148] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-148)
Newer buildings in the Market include the Post Alley Market at First and Pine (Bassetti Norton Metler, 1983), the Inn at the Market (Ibsen Nelson & Associates, 1985); and The Pike and Virginia Building (Olson/Walker, 1978); and the Market Heritage Center (Scot Carr & Thomas Schaer, 1999). All of these echo at aspects of the architecture of the historic Market buildings.
[149] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-149)
The
Pike Street Hill Climb (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Street_Hill_Climb)
(Calvin and Gorasht, 1976) connects the Market to the waterfront; it occupies the same corridor that once (roughly 1911–1935
[150] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-150)
) held a wooden overpass used by farmers to bring produce up to the Market after arriving by boat.
[151] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-151)
Listed buildings near the Market
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=15)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_1921_First_Avenue_03.jpg)
The Butterworth Building. At left, a portion of the Alaska Trade Building can also be seen, and at right the Smith Block (which dates from 1906 but is not a listed building). The three buildings were jointly restored by
Ralph Anderson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ralph_Anderson_(architect))
& Partners in 1977.
Along the southwest side of First Avenue, within the present-day historic district but outside of the original Market, the Alaska Trade Building (1915), 1915–1919 1st Avenue and the Late Victorian style Butterworth Building (originally the Butterworth mortuary, 1903), 1921 1st Avenue, are both listed in the
National Register of Historic Places (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places)
(NRHP). Outside the historic districts but within the City Clerk's definition of the Pike-Market neighborhood are the J. S. Graham Store (1919, designed by
A. E. Doyle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A._E._Doyle)
), 119 Pine Street; and the U.S. Immigration Building (1915), 84 Union Street. Other NRHP-listed buildings near the Market but outside of those boundaries include the Guiry and Schillestad Building (Young Hotel or Guiry Building 1903, Mystic Hotel or Schillestad Building 1908), 2101–2111 1st Avenue; the Renaissance-style New Washington Hotel (now Josephinum Hotel, built 1900–1949), 1902 Second Avenue; and the
Moore Theatre and Hotel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore_Theatre_(Seattle,_Washington))
(1907), 1932 2nd Avenue.
[152] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-NRHP-2006-152)
[153] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-Dorpat-88-153)
[154] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-154)
[155] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-155)
[156] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-156)
[157] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-157)
[158] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-158)
Also in the Pike-Market neighborhood but outside the historic districts are at least two
city-designated landmark (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Landmarks_in_Seattle)
not on the NRHP: the Terminal Sales Building (1923–1925), 1932 1st Avenue; and Pier 59, now home to the
Seattle Aquarium (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Aquarium)
.
[153] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Crowley-Dorpat-88-153)
[159] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-159)
[160] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-160)
Transportation
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pike_Place_Market&action=edit&section=16)
]
The main arm of the market is located along the eponymous Pike Place, a two-block street that runs northwest for approximately 940 feet (290 m) between Pike Street and Virginia Street. From 1907 to 2025 the market was open to
one-way (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_road)
automobile traffic despite its heavy pedestrian use. While previously the street only closed to automobiles during some events, efforts to create a permanent
pedestrian zone (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pedestrian_zone)
have resulted in an extended trial period starting in late April of 2025 despite having been opposed by some market vendors and business owners.
[161] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-161)
[162] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Times-CarFree-162)
The closing of the street to vehicular traffic has been described as a "perennial issue" by the PDA due to Pike Place Market's status as a working market and the need for loading zones,
[162] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-Times-CarFree-162)
which contrasts with overwhelming support from Seattle residents for restricting vehicles.
[163] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-163)
The closure to vehicular traffic was originally scheduled from April to August 2025 due to nearby
Seattle Public Utilities (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Public_Utilities)
and
Puget Sound Energy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound_Energy)
projects that resurfaced a section of Pike Place,
[164] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-164)
but has since been extended to spring 2026. Market leaders cited positive feedback from customers and vendors, increased foot traffic, increased sales, and the need for more research as justification for the extension.
[165] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-165)
[166] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-166)
The market is located near the
Westlake Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westlake_Center)
transit hub, which is served by a bus mall,
Link light rail (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Link_light_rail)
at
Westlake station (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westlake_station_(Sound_Transit))
, the
Seattle Center Monorail (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center_Monorail)
, and
South Lake Union Streetcar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Lake_Union_Streetcar)
.
[167] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-167)
An extension of the streetcar, named the Center City Connector, was planned to stop on 1st Avenue adjacent to the market but is on hold due to funding shortfalls.
[168] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-168)
[169] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pike_Place_Market#cite_note-169)

Seattle
(
/siˈætəl/ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English)
[No Text] (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/6/6e/GT_Seattle_AE.ogg/GT_Seattle_AE.ogg.mp3)
ⓘ (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:GT_Seattle_AE.ogg)
see-AT-əl (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key)
) is the
most populous city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_municipalities_in_Washington)
in the U.S. state of
Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state))
and the
Pacific Northwest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest)
region of
North America (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_America)
. It is the
18th-most populous city (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population)
in the United States with a population of 780,995 in 2024,
[3] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-QuickFacts-4)
while the
Seattle metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_metropolitan_area)
at over 4.15 million residents is the
15th-most populous metropolitan area (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_statistical_areas)
in the nation.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-12)
The city is the
county seat (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_seat)
of
King County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_County,_Washington)
, the
most populous county (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Washington)
in Washington. Seattle's growth rate of 21.1% between 2010 and 2020 made it one of the country's fastest-growing large cities.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-13)
Seattle is situated on an
isthmus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isthmus)
between
Puget Sound (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound)
, an inlet of the
Pacific Ocean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Ocean)
, and
Lake Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Washington)
. It is the northernmost major city in the United States, located about 100 miles (160 km) south of the
Canadian border (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border)
. A gateway for trade with
East Asia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia)
, the
Port of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Seattle)
is the fourth-largest port in North America in terms of container handling as of 2021
[update] (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Seattle&action=edit)
.
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-14)
The Seattle area has been inhabited by
Native Americans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States)
(such as the
Duwamish (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duwamish_people)
, who had at least 17 villages around Elliot Bay) for at least 4,000 years before the first permanent European settlers.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Discovery_Park-15)
Arthur A. Denny (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_A._Denny)
and his group of travelers, subsequently known as the
Denny Party (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_Party)
, arrived from
Illinois (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois)
via
Portland, Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon)
, on the
schoonerExact (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schooner_Exact)
at
Alki Point (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alki_Point,_Seattle)
on November 13, 1851.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-SonsOfTheProfits-16)
The settlement was moved to the eastern shore of
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
in 1852 and named "Seattle" in honor of
Chief Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Seattle)
, a prominent 19th-century leader of the local
Duwamish (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duwamish_people)
and
Suquamish (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suquamish)
tribes. Seattle currently has high populations of Native Americans alongside Americans with strong Asian, African, European, and Scandinavian ancestry, and, as of 2015, hosts the fifth-highest percentage of residents who identify as
LGBT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_Seattle)
in the U.S.
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-17)
Logging (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logging)
was Seattle's first major industry, but by the late 19th century the city had become a commercial and shipbuilding center as a gateway to
Alaska (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska)
during the
Klondike Gold Rush (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush)
. The city grew after
World War II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II)
, partly due to the local company
Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing)
, which established Seattle as a center for its manufacturing of aircraft. Beginning in the 1980s, the Seattle area developed into a
technology center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_technology_centers)
;
Microsoft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)
established its headquarters in the region.
Alaska Airlines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines)
is based at
Seattle–Tacoma International Airport (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle%E2%80%93Tacoma_International_Airport)
in
SeaTac, Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SeaTac,_Washington)
. The stream of new software,
biotechnology (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotechnology)
, and Internet companies led to an economic revival, which increased the city's population by almost 50,000 in the decade between 1990 and 2000.
The culture of Seattle is heavily defined by its
significant musical history (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Seattle)
. Between 1918 and 1951, nearly 24
jazz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jazz)
nightclubs existed along Jackson Street, from the current
Chinatown/International District (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinatown/International_District,_Seattle)
to the
Central District (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_District,_Seattle)
. The jazz scene nurtured the early careers of
Ernestine Anderson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernestine_Anderson)
,
Ray Charles (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_Charles)
,
Quincy Jones (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quincy_Jones)
, and others. In the late 20th and early 21st century, the city also was the origin of several
rock (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_music)
artists, including
Foo Fighters (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foo_Fighters)
,
Heart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart_(band))
, and
Jimi Hendrix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix)
, and the subgenre of
grunge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grunge)
and its pioneering bands, including
Alice in Chains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_in_Chains)
,
Nirvana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_(band))
,
Pearl Jam (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_Jam)
,
Soundgarden (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundgarden)
, and others.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Sound-18)
History
Main article:
History of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Seattle)
For a chronological guide, see
Timeline of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_Seattle)
.
Archaeological excavations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archaeological_excavation)
suggest that
Native Americans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States)
have inhabited the Seattle area for at least 4,000 years.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Discovery_Park-15)
By the time the first European settlers arrived, the
Duwamish people (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duwamish_people)
occupied at least 17 villages in the areas around
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
.
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-19)
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-20)
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-21)
The name for the modern city of Seattle in
Lushootseed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lushootseed)
,
dᶻidᶻəlal̓ič
, meaning "little crossing-over place", comes from one of these villages, which was located at the present-day
King Street Station (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_Street_Station)
.
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-BatesHess1994-22)
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-:0-23)
In May 1792,
George Vancouver (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Vancouver)
was the first European to visit the Seattle area during his
1791–1795 expedition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vancouver_Expedition)
for the
Royal Navy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Navy)
, which sought to chart the
Pacific Northwest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest)
for the British.
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Vancouver1801-24)
19th century
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_-_Occidental_and_Yesler_-_1884.jpg)
Seattle's first streetcar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Street_Railway)
at the corner of Occidental and Yesler in 1884; all buildings depicted were destroyed by the
Great Seattle Fire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire)
five years later, in 1889.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Birds-eye-view_of_Seattle_and_environs_King_County,_Wash.,_1891._LOC_75696663.jpg)
An 1891 aerial view of Seattle and surrounding
King County (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_County,_Washington)
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-25)
In 1851, a large party of
American pioneers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_pioneer)
led by Luther Collins made a location on land at the mouth of the
Duwamish River (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duwamish_River)
; they formally claimed it on September 14, 1851.
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-26)
Thirteen days later, members of the Collins Party on the way to their claim passed three scouts of the Denny Party.
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-27)
Members of the Denny Party claimed land on
Alki Point (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alki_Point,_Seattle)
on September 28, 1851.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-founding-28)
The rest of the Denny Party set sail on the
schoonerExact (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schooner_Exact)
from
Portland (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland,_Oregon)
, Oregon, stopping in
Astoria (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astoria,_Oregon)
, and landed at Alki Point during a rainstorm on November 13, 1851.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-founding-28)
After a difficult winter, most of the Denny Party relocated across Elliott Bay and claimed land a second time at the site of present-day
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle)
,
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-founding-28)
naming this new settlement
Duwamps
.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-29)
Charles Terry and John Low remained at the original landing location, reestablished their old land claim and called it "New York", but renamed "New York Alki" in April 1853, from a
Chinook (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinook_Jargon)
word meaning, roughly, "by and by" or "someday".
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-30)
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-ws-31)
For the next few years, New York Alki and Duwamps competed for dominance, but in time Alki was abandoned and its residents moved across the bay to join the rest of the settlers.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-32)
David Swinson "Doc" Maynard (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Swinson_Maynard)
, one of the founders of Duwamps, was the primary advocate to name the settlement after
Chief Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Seattle)
(
Lushootseed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lushootseed_language)
:
siʔaɫ
, anglicized as "Seattle"), chief of the Duwamish and
Suquamish (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suquamish)
tribes.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-nameorigin-33)
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-34)
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-35)
The brief
Puget Sound War (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound_War)
culminated in the
Battle of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Seattle_(1856))
on January 26, 1856. The attack was repelled, and the settlement was never attacked again.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-36)
The name "Seattle" appears on official
Washington Territory (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Territory)
papers dated May 23, 1853, when the first plats for the village were filed. In 1855, nominal land settlements were established. On January 14, 1865, the Legislature of Territorial Washington incorporated the Town of Seattle with a
board of trustees (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trustee_model_of_representation)
managing the city. The Town of Seattle was disincorporated on January 18, 1867, and remained a mere precinct of King County until late 1869, when a new petition was filed and the city was re-incorporated December 2, 1869, with a
mayor–council government (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mayor%E2%80%93council_government)
.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-founding-28)
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-37)
The corporate seal of the City of Seattle carries the date "1869" and a likeness of Chief Seattle in left profile.
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-38)
That same year, Seattle acquired the epithet of the "Queen City", a designation officially changed in 1982 to the "Emerald City".
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-39)
Seattle has a history of boom-and-bust cycles, like many other cities near areas of extensive natural and mineral resources. Seattle has risen several times economically, then gone into precipitous decline, but it has typically used those periods to rebuild solid infrastructure.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-shear-40)
The first such boom, covering the early years of the city, rode on the lumber industry. During this period the road now known as
Yesler Way (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yesler_Way)
won the nickname "Skid Road", supposedly after the timber skidding down the hill to
Henry Yesler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Yesler)
's sawmill. The later dereliction of the area may be a possible origin for the term which later entered the wider American lexicon as
Skid Row (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skid_Row)
.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-yesler-41)
Like much of the
U.S. West (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_United_States)
, Seattle experienced conflicts between labor and management and ethnic tensions that culminated in the
anti-Chinese riots of 1885–1886 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Seattle_before_1900#Relations_between_whites_and_Chinese)
.
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Kinnear_1911-42)
This violence originated with unemployed whites who were determined to drive the Chinese from Seattle; anti-Chinese riots also occurred in
Tacoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tacoma_riot_of_1885)
.
Seattle had achieved sufficient economic success when the
Great Seattle Fire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Seattle_Fire)
of 1889 destroyed the central business district. However, a far grander city center rapidly emerged in its place.
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-fire-43)
Finance company
Washington Mutual (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Mutual)
, for example, was founded in the immediate wake of the fire.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Klondike-foundings-44)
The
Panic of 1893 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panic_of_1893)
hit Seattle hard.
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-45)
The second and most dramatic boom resulted from the
Klondike Gold Rush (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush)
, which ended the depression that had begun with the
Panic of 1893 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panic_of_1893)
. In a short time, Seattle became a major transportation center. On July 14, 1897, the
S.S. Portland
docked with its famed "ton of gold", and Seattle became the main transport and supply point for the miners in
Alaska (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska)
and the
Yukon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yukon)
. Few of those working men found lasting wealth. However, it was Seattle's business of clothing the miners and feeding them salmon that panned out in the long run. Along with Seattle, other cities like
Everett (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everett,_Washington)
,
Tacoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tacoma,_Washington)
,
Port Townsend (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Townsend,_Washington)
,
Bremerton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bremerton,_Washington)
, and
Olympia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympia,_Washington)
, all in the Puget Sound region, became competitors for exchange, rather than
mother lodes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother_lode)
for extraction, of precious metals.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-46)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_1870.jpg)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_1870.jpg)
A September 1870 engraving of Seattle published in
Harper's Magazine (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harper%27s_Magazine)
20th century
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Pioneer_square.jpg)
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle)
, the
Pioneer Building (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Building_(Seattle,_Washington))
, the
Smith Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smith_Tower)
, and the
Seattle Hotel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Hotel)
in 1917
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_Monorail_under_construction_-_1961.jpg)
The
Seattle Center Monorail (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center_Monorail)
under construction in 1961
The boom lasted into the early part of the 20th century, and funded many new Seattle companies and products. In 1907, 19-year-old
James E. Casey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_E._Casey)
borrowed $100 from a friend and founded the
American Messenger Company (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Messenger_Company)
(later
UPS (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Parcel_Service)
). Other Seattle companies founded during this period include
Nordstrom (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordstrom)
and
Eddie Bauer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eddie_Bauer)
.
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Klondike-foundings-44)
Seattle brought in the
Olmsted Brothers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olmsted_Brothers)
landscape architecture firm to design a system of parks and boulevards.
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-47)
The Gold Rush era culminated in the
Alaska–Yukon–Pacific Exposition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska%E2%80%93Yukon%E2%80%93Pacific_Exposition)
of 1909, which is largely responsible for the layout of today's
University of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Washington)
campus.
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-aypexpo-48)
A
shipbuilding (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shipbuilding)
boom in the early part of the 20th century became massive during
World War I (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I)
, making Seattle somewhat of a company town. The subsequent retrenchment led to the
Seattle General Strike of 1919 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_General_Strike)
, an early
general strike (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_strike)
in the country.
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-generalstrike-49)
A 1912 city development plan by
Virgil Bogue (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgil_Bogue)
went largely unused. Seattle was mildly prosperous in the 1920s but was particularly hard hit in the Great Depression, experiencing some of the country's harshest labor strife in that era. Violence during the
Maritime Strike of 1934 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_Strike_of_1934)
cost Seattle much of its maritime traffic, which was rerouted to the
Port of Los Angeles (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Los_Angeles)
.
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-50)
Seattle was one of the major cities that benefited from programs such as the
Works Progress Administration (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Works_Progress_Administration)
,
CCC (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civilian_Conservation_Corps)
,
Public Works Administration (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Works_Administration)
, and others.
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-51)
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-52)
The workers, mostly men, built roads, parks, dams, schools, railroads, bridges, docks, and even historical and archival record sites and buildings. Seattle faced significant unemployment, loss of lumber and construction industries as
Los Angeles (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles)
prevailed as the bigger
West Coast (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States)
city. Seattle had building contracts that rivaled
New York City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City)
and
Chicago (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago)
, but also lost to Los Angeles. Seattle's eastern farm land faded due to
Oregon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon)
's and the
Midwest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwestern_United_States)
's, forcing people into town.
[52] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-53)
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-54)
Hooverville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hooverville)
arose during the Depression, leading to Seattle's growing homeless population. Stationed outside Seattle, the Hooverville housed thousands of men but very few children and no women. With work projects close to the city, Hooverville grew and the WPA settled into the city.
[54] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-55)
A movement of women arose from Seattle during the
Great Depression (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression)
, fueled in part by
Eleanor Roosevelt (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eleanor_Roosevelt)
's 1933 book
It's Up to the Women
; women pushed for recognition, not just as housewives, but as the backbone to family. Using newspapers and journals
Working Woman
and
The Woman Today
, women pushed to be seen as equal and receive some recognition.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-56)
The Great Depression did not impact the
University of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Washington)
negatively. As schools across Washington lost funding and attendance, the university actually prospered during the time period as they focused on growing their student enrollment. While
Seattle public schools (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Public_Schools)
were influenced by Washington's superintendent Worth McClure,
[56] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-57)
they still struggled to pay teachers and maintain attendance.
[57] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-58)
Seattle was the home base of impresario
Alexander Pantages (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Pantages)
who, starting in 1902, opened a number of theaters in the city exhibiting
vaudeville (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaudeville)
acts and silent movies. He went on to become one of America's greatest theater and movie tycoons. Scottish-born architect
B. Marcus Priteca (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B._Marcus_Priteca)
designed several theaters for Pantages in Seattle, which were later demolished or converted to other uses. Seattle's surviving
Paramount Theatre (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paramount_Theatre_(Seattle))
, on which he collaborated, was not a Pantages theater.
[58] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-59)
War work again brought local prosperity during
World War II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II)
, centered on the production of
Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing)
aircraft. The war dispersed the city's numerous Japanese-American businessmen due to the
Japanese American internment (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_American_internment)
. After the World War II, however, the local economy dipped. It rose again with Boeing's growing dominance in the commercial
airliner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airliner)
market.
[59] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-60)
Seattle celebrated its restored prosperity and made a bid for world recognition with the
Century 21 Exposition (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Century_21_Exposition)
, the
1962 World's Fair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Century_21_Exposition)
, for which the
Space Needle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle)
was built.
[60] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-worldsfair-61)
Another major local economic downturn was in the late 1960s and early 1970s, at a time when Boeing was heavily affected by the
oil crises (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1970s_energy_crisis)
, loss of government contracts, and costs and delays associated with the
Boeing 747 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_747)
. Many people left the area to look for work elsewhere, and two local real estate agents put up a billboard reading "Will the last person leaving Seattle – Turn out the lights."
[61] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-62)
Seattle remained the corporate headquarters of Boeing until 2001, when the company separated its headquarters from its major production facilities; the headquarters were moved to Chicago.
[62] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-63)
The Seattle area is still home to Boeing's
Renton narrow-body plant (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Renton_Factory)
and
Everett wide-body plant (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Everett_Factory)
.
[63] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-64)
The company's
credit union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_union)
for employees,
BECU (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BECU)
, remains based in the Seattle area and has been open to all residents of Washington since 2002.
[64] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-65)
On March 20, 1970, twenty-eight people were killed when the Ozark Hotel was burned by an unknown arsonist.
[65] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-66)
The
Wah Mee massacre (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wah_Mee_massacre)
in 1983 resulted in the killing of 13 people in an illegal gambling club in the
Seattle Chinatown-International District (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Chinatown-International_District)
.
[66] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-67)
The city's first
coffeehouses (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_in_Seattle)
were established in the late 1950s and grew over the following decades as espresso was introduced to the American market. On March 30, 1971, the
first location (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_Starbucks)
for
Starbucks Coffee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starbucks)
opened at Pike Place Market in Downtown Seattle. The company initially sold
coffee beans (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_bean)
but later expanded into cafes.
[67] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-68)
Prosperity began to return in the 1980s beginning with
Microsoft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)
's 1979 move from
Albuquerque, New Mexico (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico)
, to nearby
Bellevue, Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington)
.
[68] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-69)
Seattle and its suburbs became home to a number of technology companies, including
Amazon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(company))
,
F5 Networks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F5_Networks)
,
RealNetworks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RealNetworks)
,
Nintendo of America (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nintendo_of_America)
, and
T-Mobile (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-Mobile_US)
.
[69] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-70)
This success brought an influx of new residents with a population increase within city limits of almost 50,000 between 1990 and 2000,
[70] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pophistory-71)
and saw Seattle's real estate become some of the most expensive in the country.
[71] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-72)
Seattle in this period attracted attention as home to the companies opened operations in or around the city. In 1990, the
Goodwill Games (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goodwill_Games)
were held in the city.
[72] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-goodwillgames-73)
Three years later, in 1993, the
APEC (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/APEC)
leaders was hosted in Seattle.
[73] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-74)
The 1990s also witnessed a growing popularity in
grunge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grunge)
music, a sound that was largely developed in Seattle's independent music scene.
[74] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-75)
In 1993, the movie
Sleepless in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleepless_in_Seattle)
brought the city further national attention,
[75] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-76)
as did the television sitcom
Frasier (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frasier)
. The
dot-com boom (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dot-com_bubble)
caused a great frenzy among the technology companies in Seattle but the bubble ended in early 2001.
[76] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-77)
[77] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-78)
In 1999, the
World Trade Organization (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_1999)
held its conference in Seattle, which was met with
protest activity (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_1999_protest_activity)
. The protests and police reactions to them largely overshadowed the conference itself.
[78] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-wto-79)
21st century
In 2001, the city was impacted by the
Mardi Gras Riots (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Mardi_Gras_Riots)
and then by the
Nisqually earthquake (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Nisqually_earthquake)
the following day.
[79] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-80)
Another boom began as the city emerged from the
Great Recession (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession)
, commencing when
Amazon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(company))
moved its headquarters from North
Beacon Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beacon_Hill,_Seattle)
to
South Lake Union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Lake_Union,_Seattle)
. The move initiated a historic construction boom which resulted in the completion of almost 10,000 apartments in Seattle in 2017, more than any previous year and nearly twice as many as were built in 2016.
[80] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-81)
[81] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Rosenberg-82)
By 2025, Seattle's new apartments had become the smallest in the U.S., with an average of 649 square feet (60.3 m
2
) among all unit types.
[82] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-83)
From 2010 to 2015, Seattle gained an average of 14,511 residents per year, with the growth strongly skewed toward the center of the city,
[83] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-84)
and unemployment dropped from roughly 9 percent to 3.6 percent.
[84] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pi-slu-boom-85)
The city has found itself "bursting at the seams", with over 45,000 households spending more than half their income on housing and
at least 2,800 people homeless (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homelessness_in_Seattle)
, and with the country's sixth-worst rush-hour traffic.
[84] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pi-slu-boom-85)
In response, many
urbanist (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urbanism)
measures to improve transit, cycling,
[85] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-86)
and housing affordability were passed by city council, the state, and voters.
[86] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-87)
[87] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-88)
These include
Sound Transit 3 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sound_Transit_3)
, Seattle Prop 1A,
[88] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-89)
a "Downtown Activation Plan,"
[89] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-90)
and a new "One Seattle" Comprehensive Plan.
[90] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-91)
Geography
Topography
See also:
Bodies of water of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bodies_of_water_of_Seattle)
,
List of neighborhoods in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_neighborhoods_in_Seattle)
, and
Regrading in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regrading_in_Seattle)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_by_Sentinel-2,_2018-09-28.jpg)
A satellite photo of Seattle in September 2018
Seattle is located between the saltwater
Puget Sound (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound)
(an arm of the Pacific Ocean) to the west and
Lake Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Washington)
to the east. The city's chief harbor,
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
, is part of Puget Sound, making the city an oceanic port. To the west, beyond Puget Sound, are the
Kitsap Peninsula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitsap_Peninsula)
and
Olympic Mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Mountains)
on the
Olympic Peninsula (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Peninsula)
; to the east, beyond Lake Washington and the
Eastside (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastside_(King_County,_Washington))
suburbs, are
Lake Sammamish (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Sammamish)
and the
Cascade Range (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascade_Range)
. Lake Washington's waters flow to Puget Sound through the
Lake Washington Ship Canal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Washington_Ship_Canal)
(consisting of two man-made canals,
Lake Union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Union)
, and the
Hiram M. Chittenden Locks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiram_M._Chittenden_Locks)
at
Salmon Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salmon_Bay)
, ending in
Shilshole Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shilshole_Bay)
on Puget Sound).
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
The sea, rivers, forests, lakes, and fields surrounding Seattle were once rich enough to support one of the world's few sedentary
hunter-gatherer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter-gatherer)
societies. In modern times the surrounding area lends itself well to sailing, skiing, bicycling, camping, and hiking year-round.
[91] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-92)
[92] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-93)
The city is hilly in some places.
[93] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-94)
Like Rome, the city is said to lie on
seven hills (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seven_hills_of_Seattle)
;
[94] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-95)
the lists vary but typically include
Capitol Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitol_Hill,_Seattle)
,
First Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Hill,_Seattle)
,
West Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Seattle)
,
Beacon Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beacon_Hill,_Seattle)
,
Queen Anne (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen_Anne,_Seattle)
, Magnolia, and the former
Denny Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Denny_Hill)
. The
Wallingford (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallingford,_Seattle)
,
Delridge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delridge,_Seattle)
,
Mount Baker (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Baker,_Seattle)
,
Seward Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seward_Park,_Seattle)
,
Washington Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Park,_Seattle)
,
Broadmoor (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadmoor,_Seattle)
,
Madrona (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrona,_Seattle)
,
Phinney Ridge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phinney_Ridge,_Seattle)
,
Sunset Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunset_Hill,_Seattle)
,
Blue Ridge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Ridge,_Seattle)
,
Broadview (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadview,_Seattle)
,
Laurelhurst (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurelhurst,_Seattle)
,
Hawthorne Hills (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hawthorne_Hills,_Seattle)
,
Maple Leaf (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maple_Leaf,_Seattle)
, and
Crown Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crown_Hill,_Seattle)
neighborhoods are all located on hills. Many of the hilliest areas are near the city center, with Capitol Hill, First Hill, and Beacon Hill collectively constituting something of a ridge along an isthmus between Elliott Bay and Lake Washington.
[95] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-96)
The break in the ridge between First Hill and Beacon Hill is man-made, a result of two of the many
regrading projects (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regrading_in_Seattle)
that reshaped the topography of the city center.
[96] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-97)
The topography of the city center was also changed by the construction of a
seawall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seawall)
and the artificial
Harbor Island (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harbor_Island,_Seattle)
(completed 1909) at the mouth of the city's industrial
Duwamish Waterway (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duwamish_Waterway)
, the terminus of the
Green River (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_River_(Duwamish_River_tributary))
. The highest point within city limits, 520 feet (160 m) above sea level, is at Myrtle Reservoir Park in the
High Point (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_Point,_Seattle)
neighborhood of West Seattle.
[97] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Times-Hill-98)
North of the city center, the Lake Washington Ship Canal connects Puget Sound to Lake Washington. It incorporates four natural bodies of water:
Lake Union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Union)
,
Salmon Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salmon_Bay)
,
Portage Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portage_Bay)
, and
Union Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Bay_(Seattle))
.
[98] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-99)
Due to its location in the
Pacific Ring of Fire (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Ring_of_Fire)
, Seattle is in a major
earthquake zone (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seismic_zone)
. On February 28, 2001, the
magnitude 6.8 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richter_magnitude_scale)
Nisqually earthquake (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Nisqually_earthquake)
did significant architectural damage, especially in the
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle)
area (built on
reclaimed land (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_reclamation)
, as are the
Industrial District (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_District,_Seattle)
and part of the city center), and caused one fatality.
[99] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-100)
Other strong earthquakes occurred on
January 26, 1700 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1700_Cascadia_earthquake)
(estimated at 9 magnitude),
December 14, 1872 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1872_North_Cascades_earthquake)
(7.3 or 7.4),
[100] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-101)
April 13, 1949 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1949_Olympia_earthquake)
(7.1),
[101] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-1949-quake-102)
and April 29, 1965 (6.5).
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-1965-quake-103)
The
1965 quake (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1965_Puget_Sound_earthquake)
caused three deaths in Seattle directly and one more by heart failure.
[102] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-1965-quake-103)
Although the
Seattle Fault (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Fault)
passes just south of the city center, neither it
[103] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-104)
nor the
Cascadia subduction zone (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascadia_subduction_zone)
has caused an earthquake since the city's founding. The Cascadia subduction zone poses the threat of an earthquake of magnitude 9.0 or greater, capable of seriously damaging the city and collapsing many buildings, especially in zones built on fill.
[104] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-105)
According to the
U.S. Census Bureau (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau)
, the city has a total area of 142.5 square miles (369 km
2
),
[105] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-GR1-106)
84 square miles (220 km
2
) of which is land and 58.1 square miles (150 km
2
) is water (41% of the total area).
[1] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-CenPopGazetteer-2)
Cityscape
Further information:
List of tallest buildings in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Seattle)
and
Architecture of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_of_Seattle)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_3.jpg)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_3.jpg)
A Seattle skyline view from Queen Anne Hill, including the
Space Needle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle)
,
Climate Pledge Arena (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_Pledge_Arena)
,
Mount Rainier (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Rainier)
,
Elliott Bay (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliott_Bay)
, and the Port of Seattle on
Puget Sound (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound)
Climate
Main article:
Climate of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_Seattle)
According to the
Köppen climate classification (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification)
system, Seattle has a warm-summer
Mediterranean climate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_climate)
(
Csb
),
[106] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-107)
[107] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-108)
[108] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-109)
while under the
Trewartha (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trewartha_climate_classification)
system, it is labeled an
oceanic climate (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceanic_climate)
(
Dobk
).
[109] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-110)
[110] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-111)
It has cool, wet winters and mild, relatively dry summers, covering characteristics of both climate types.
[111] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-112)
[112] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-113)
The climate is sometimes characterized as a "modified Mediterranean" climate because it is cooler and wetter than a "true" Mediterranean climate, but shares the characteristic dry summer (which has a strong influence on the region's vegetation).
[113] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-GobleHirt2012-114)
Temperature extremes are moderated by the adjacent
Puget Sound (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puget_Sound)
, greater
Pacific Ocean (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Ocean)
, and
Lake Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Washington)
. Thus extreme
heat waves (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_wave)
are rare in the Seattle area, as are very cold temperatures (below about 15 °F; −9 °C). The Seattle area is the cloudiest region of the
Continental United States (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_United_States)
, due in part to frequent storms and
lows (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-pressure_area)
moving in from the adjacent Pacific Ocean. Seattle is cloudy 201 days out of the year and partly cloudy 93 days.
[114] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-cloudy-115)
With many more "rain days" than other major American cities, Seattle has a well-earned reputation for frequent rain:
[115] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-rainshadow-116)
In an average year, there are 150 days in which at least 0.01 inches (0.25 mm) of precipitation falls, more days than in nearly all U.S. cities east of the
Rocky Mountains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rocky_Mountains)
.
[116] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-117)
However, because it often has merely a light drizzle falling from the sky for many days, Seattle actually receives significantly less rainfall (or other precipitation) overall than many other major U.S. cities like
New York City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_City)
,
Miami (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami)
, or
Houston (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Houston)
.

Demographics
Main article:
Demographics of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_Seattle)
According to the 2012–2016
American Community Survey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Community_Survey)
(ACS), the racial makeup of the city was 65.7%
White Non-Hispanic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Non-Hispanic)
, 16.9%
Asian (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_American)
, 6.8%
Black or African American (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_American)
, 6.6%
Hispanic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hispanics_in_the_United_States)
or
Latino (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans)
of any race, 0.4%
Native American (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States)
, 0.9%
Pacific Islander (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Islander_American)
, 0.2% other races, and 5.6%
two or more races (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiracial_American)
.

Seattle's population historically has been predominantly white.
[126] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pop-129)
The 2010 census showed that Seattle was one of the whitest big cities in the country, although its proportion of white residents has been gradually declining.
[127] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-131)
In 1960, whites constituted 91.6% of the city's population,
[126] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pop-129)
while in 2010 they constituted 69.5%.
[128] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-factfinder2.census.gov-132)
[129] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-c2010-133)
According to the 2006–2008
American Community Survey (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Community_Survey)
, approximately 78.9% of residents over the age of five spoke only English at home. Those who spoke
Asian languages (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_Asia)
other than Indo-European languages made up 10.2% of the population, Spanish was spoken by 4.5% of the population, speakers of other
Indo-European languages (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_languages)
made up 3.9%, and speakers of other languages made up 2.5%.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]

Seattle's foreign-born population grew 40% between the 1990 and 2000 censuses.
[130] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-brookings-134)
The
Chinese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_American)
population in the Seattle area has origins in
mainland China (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mainland_China)
, Hong Kong, Southeast Asia, and
Taiwan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taiwan)
. The earliest Chinese-Americans that came in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were almost entirely from
Guangdong Province (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guangdong_Province)
. The Seattle area is also home to a large
Vietnamese (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnamese_American)
population of more than 55,000 residents,
[131] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-135)
as well as over 30,000
Somali (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Somali_American)
immigrants.
[132] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Lsts-136)
The Seattle-Tacoma area is also home to one of the largest
Cambodian (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodian_American)
communities in the United States, numbering about 19,000 Cambodian Americans,
[133] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Turnbull2004-137)
and one of the largest
Samoan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samoan_American)
communities in the mainland U.S., with over 15,000 people having Samoan ancestry.
[128] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-factfinder2.census.gov-132)
[134] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pugetsoundsamoan-138)
Additionally, the Seattle area had the highest percentage of self-identified mixed-race people of any large metropolitan area in the United States, according to the 2000 United States Census Bureau.
[135] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-139)
According to a 2012
HistoryLink (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HistoryLink)
study, Seattle's 98118 ZIP code (in the Columbia City neighborhood) was one of the most diverse ZIP Code Tabulation Areas in the United States.
[136] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-zipcode-140)
According to the ACS 1-year estimates, in 2018, the median income of a city household was $93,481, and the median income for a family was $130,656.
[137] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-income-141)
11.0% of the population and 6.6% of families were below the poverty line. Of people living in poverty, 11.4% were under the age of 18 and 10.9% were 65 or older.
[137] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-income-141)
According to a 2024 study by
Henley & Partners (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henley_%26_Partners)
, the city of Seattle has an estimated 54,200 millionaires and 11 billionaires.
[138] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-142)
It is estimated that King County has 8,000 homeless people on any given night, and many of those live in Seattle.
[139] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-143)
In September 2005, King County adopted a "Ten-Year Plan to End Homelessness", one of the near-term results of which is a shift of funding from
homeless shelter (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homeless_shelter)
beds to permanent housing.
[140] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-homelessness-144)
In recent years, the city has experienced steady population growth, and has been faced with the issue of accommodating more residents. In 2006, after growing by 4,000 citizens per year for the previous 16 years, regional planners expected the population of Seattle to grow by 200,000 people by 2040.
[141] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Young2006-145)
However, former mayor Greg Nickels supported plans that would increase the population by 60%, or 350,000 people, by 2040 and worked on ways to accommodate this growth while keeping Seattle's single-family housing zoning laws.
[141] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Young2006-145)
The Seattle City Council later voted to relax height limits on buildings in the greater part of Downtown, partly with the aim to increase residential density in the city center.
[142] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-146)
As a sign of increasing downtown core growth, the
Downtown (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Seattle)
population crested to over 60,000 in 2009, up 77% since 1990.
[143] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-147)
In 2021, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Seattle experienced its first population decline in 50 years.
[144] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-148)
However, this was followed by five straight years of population growth that exceeded 2% per year. According to state estimates, Seattle surpassed 800,000 residents in 2025.
[145] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-149)
Seattle has a relatively high number of adults living alone. According to the 2000 U.S. Census interim measurements of 2004, Seattle has the fifth highest proportion of single-person households nationwide among cities of 100,000 or more residents, at 40.8%.
[146] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-150)
Sexual orientation and gender identity
See also:
History of the LGBTQ community in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_LGBTQ_community_in_Seattle)
,
LGBT culture in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_Seattle)
, and
Seattle Pride (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Pride)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_Pride_Fest_2024_main_stage.jpg)
Seattle Pride Fest 2024
Seattle has a notably large
lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LGBT)
community. According to a 2006 study by
UCLA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles)
, 12.9% of city residents polled identified as gay, lesbian, or bisexual. This was the second-highest proportion of any major U.S. city, behind
San Francisco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Francisco)
.
[147] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-gates_06-151)
Greater Seattle also ranked second among major U.S. metropolitan areas, with 6.5% of the population identifying as gay, lesbian, or bisexual.
[147] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-gates_06-151)
According to 2012 estimates from the United States Census Bureau, Seattle has the highest percentage of same-sex households in the United States, at 2.6 percent, surpassing San Francisco (2.5 percent).
[148] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-152)
The
Capitol Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitol_Hill,_Seattle)
district has been the center of LGBTQ culture in Seattle
[149] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-153)
since the 1970s. Before then, the
Pioneer Square (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pioneer_Square,_Seattle)
district was the city's hub of LGBTQ community.
[150] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Freitas2017-154)
