List of companies based in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_companies_based_in_Seattle)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wamuseattle.jpg)
Washington Mutual (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Mutual)
's last headquarters, the WaMu Center, now the
Russell Investments Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russell_Investments_Center)
, (center left), and its prior headquarters, Washington Mutual Tower, now the
1201 Third Avenue (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1201_Third_Avenue)
Tower
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Day_1_Tower_Seattle_WA_Jan_17.jpg)
The corporate headquarters of online retailer
Amazon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_(company))
, named Day 1 and located in Denny Triangle
Seattle's economy is driven by a mix of older industrial companies and new-economy internet and technology companies, as well as service, design, and
clean technology (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clean_technology)
companies. The city's gross metropolitan product (GMP) was $231 billion in 2010, making it the
11th-largest metropolitan economy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_the_United_States_by_GMP)
in the United States.
[151] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-155)
[152] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-156)
The
Port of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Seattle)
, which also operates
Seattle–Tacoma International Airport (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle%E2%80%93Tacoma_International_Airport)
, is a major gateway for trade with Asia and cruises to Alaska. It also is the 8th-largest port in the United States when measured by container capacity. Its maritime cargo operations merged with the
Port of Tacoma (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_of_Tacoma)
in 2015 to form the
Northwest Seaport Alliance (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Seaport_Alliance)
.
[153] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-157)
[154] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-158)
Although it was impacted by the
Great Recession (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Recession_in_the_United_States)
, Seattle has retained a comparatively strong economy, and is noted for start-up businesses, especially in green building and clean technologies.
[155] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-159)
In February 2010, the city government committed Seattle to become North America's first "climate neutral" city, with a goal of reaching net-zero per-capita greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.
[156] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-160)
Large companies continue to dominate the business landscape. Seven companies on
Fortune500 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortune_500)
's 2022 list of the United States' largest companies (based on total revenue) are headquartered in Seattle: Internet retailer
Amazon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon.com)
(#2), coffee chain
Starbucks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starbucks)
(#120), freight forwarder
Expeditors International of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expeditors_International_of_Washington)
(#225), department store
Nordstrom (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordstrom)
(#245), forest products company
Weyerhaeuser (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weyerhaeuser)
(#354), online travel company
Expedia Group (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expedia_Group)
(#404), and real-estate tech company
Zillow (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zillow)
(#424) .
[157] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Fortune500-161)
Other Fortune 500 companies commonly associated with Seattle are based in nearby Puget Sound cities. Warehouse club chain
Costco (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Costco)
(#11), the largest retail company in Washington, is based in
Issaquah (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Issaquah,_Washington)
.
Microsoft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft)
(#14) is located in
Redmond (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redmond,_Washington)
. Furthermore, Bellevue is home to truck manufacturer
Paccar (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paccar)
(#151).
[157] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Fortune500-161)
Other major companies headquartered in the area include
Nintendo of America (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nintendo_of_America)
in Redmond,
T-Mobile US (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-Mobile_US)
in Bellevue, and
Providence Health & Services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Providence_Health_%26_Services)
(the state's largest health care system and fifth-largest employer) in
Renton (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renton,_Washington)
. The city has a reputation for heavy
coffee consumption (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_in_Seattle)
;
[158] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-nyt-coffee-162)
coffee companies founded or based in Seattle include Starbucks,
[159] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-163)
Seattle's Best Coffee (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle%27s_Best_Coffee)
,
[160] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-164)
and
Tully's (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tully%27s_Coffee)
.
[161] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-165)
There are also many successful independent artisanal espresso roasters and cafés.
[158] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-nyt-coffee-162)
[
needs update (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items)
]
Before moving its headquarters to
Chicago (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicago)
and then ultimately
Arlington County, Virginia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlington_County,_Virginia)
, aerospace manufacturer
Boeing (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing)
(#60) was the largest company based in Seattle. Its largest division,
Boeing Commercial Airplanes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Commercial_Airplanes)
, is still headquartered within the Puget Sound region.
[162] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-166)
[e] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-167)
The company also has large aircraft manufacturing plants in Everett and Renton; it remains the largest private employer in the Seattle metropolitan area.
[163] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-168)
In 2006 former Seattle Mayor Greg Nickels announced a desire to spark a new economic boom driven by the
biotechnology (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biotechnology)
industry. Major redevelopment of the
South Lake Union (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Lake_Union,_Seattle)
neighborhood is underway in an effort to attract new and established biotech companies to the city, joining biotech companies
Corixa (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corixa_(company))
(acquired by
GlaxoSmithKline (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GlaxoSmithKline)
), Immunex (now part of Amgen),
Trubion (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trubion)
, and ZymoGenetics.
Vulcan Inc. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vulcan_Inc.)
, the holding company of billionaire
Paul Allen (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Allen)
, is behind most of the development projects in the region. While some see the new development as an economic boon, others have criticized Nickels and the
Seattle City Council (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_City_Council)
for pandering to Allen's interests at taxpayers' expense.
[164] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-169)
In 2005,
Forbes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes)
ranked Seattle as the most expensive American city for buying a house based on the local income levels.
[165] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Clemence-170)
Owing largely to the rapidly increasing cost of living, Seattle and Washington State have some of the
highest minimum wages in the country (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_wage_in_the_United_States)
, at $15 per hour for smaller businesses and $16 for the city's largest employers.
[166] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-171)
Operating a hub at Seattle–Tacoma International Airport,
Alaska Airlines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alaska_Airlines)
maintains its headquarters in the city of
SeaTac (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SeaTac,_Washington)
, next to the airport.
[167] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-172)
Seattle is a hub for global health with the headquarters of the
Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_%26_Melinda_Gates_Foundation)
,
PATH (global health organization) (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PATH_(global_health_organization))
,
Infectious Disease Research Institute (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infectious_Disease_Research_Institute)
,
Fred Hutchinson Cancer Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fred_Hutchinson_Cancer_Center)
, and the
Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Health_Metrics_and_Evaluation)
. In 2015, the Washington Global Health Alliance counted 168 global health organizations in Washington state. Many are headquartered in Seattle.
[168] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-173)
Culture
Many of
Seattle's neighborhoods (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_neighborhoods_in_Seattle)
host one or more
street fairs or parades (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Seattle_street_fairs_and_parades)
.
[169] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-174)
Performing arts
Main articles:
Arts in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arts_in_Seattle)
and
Music of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Seattle)
See also:
List of musicians from Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_musicians_from_Seattle)
and
List of songs about Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_songs_about_Seattle)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kreielsheimer_Promenade_04.jpg)
Kreielsheimer Promenade (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kreielsheimer_Promenade)
and
Marion Oliver McCaw Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion_Oliver_McCaw_Hall)
at
Seattle Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Center)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Benaroya_Hall,_Seattle,_Washington,_USA.jpg)
Benaroya Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benaroya_Hall)
, home of the
Seattle Symphony (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Symphony)
since 1998
Seattle has been a regional center for the
performing arts (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Performing_arts)
for many years. The century-old
Seattle Symphony Orchestra (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Symphony_Orchestra)
has won many awards and performs primarily at
Benaroya Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benaroya_Hall)
.
[170] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-175)
The
Seattle Opera (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Opera)
and
Pacific Northwest Ballet (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pacific_Northwest_Ballet)
, which perform at
McCaw Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCaw_Hall)
(opened in 2003 on the site of the former Seattle Opera House at Seattle Center), are comparably distinguished,
[171] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-pnb-176)
[172] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-177)
with the Opera being particularly known for its performances of the works of
Richard Wagner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Wagner)
[173] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-178)
[174] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-179)
and the PNB School (founded in 1974) ranking as one of the top three ballet training institutions in the United States.
[175] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-180)
The
Seattle Youth Symphony Orchestras (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Youth_Symphony_Orchestras)
(SYSO) is the largest symphonic youth organization in the United States.
[176] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-181)
The city also boasts lauded summer and winter
chamber music (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chamber_music)
festivals organized by the
Seattle Chamber Music Society (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Chamber_Music_Society)
.
[177] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-182)
The
5th Avenue Theatre (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5th_Avenue_Theatre)
, built in 1926, stages
Broadway-style (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Broadway_theatre)
musical shows
[178] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-183)
featuring both local talent and international stars.
[179] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-184)
Seattle has "around 100" theatrical production companies
[180] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Kiley-new-theater-185)
and over two dozen live theatre venues, many of them associated with
fringe theatre (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fringe_theatre)
;
[181] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-186)
[182] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-187)
Seattle is probably second only to New York for number of
equity (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actors%27_Equity_Association)
theaters
[183] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-188)
(28 Seattle theater companies have some sort of
Actors' Equity (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actors%27_Equity)
contract).
[180] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Kiley-new-theater-185)
In addition, the 900-seat
Romanesque Revival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romanesque_Revival_architecture)
Town Hall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town_Hall_Seattle)
on First Hill hosts numerous cultural events, especially lectures and recitals.
[184] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-189)
Between 1918 and 1951, there were nearly two dozen jazz nightclubs along Jackson Street, running from the current Chinatown/International District to the Central District. The jazz scene developed the early careers of
Ray Charles (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ray_Charles)
,
Quincy Jones (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quincy_Jones)
,
Bumps Blackwell (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bumps_Blackwell)
,
Ernestine Anderson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernestine_Anderson)
, and others.
[185] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Music-190)
Early popular musical acts from the Seattle/Puget Sound area include the collegiate folk group
The Brothers Four (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Brothers_Four)
, vocal group
The Fleetwoods (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Fleetwoods)
, 1960s garage rockers
The Wailers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wailers_(rock_band))
and
The Sonics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sonics)
, and instrumental surf group
The Ventures (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Ventures)
, some of whom are still active.
[185] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Music-190)
Seattle is considered the home of
grunge (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grunge)
music,
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Sound-18)
having produced artists such as
Nirvana (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nirvana_(band))
,
Soundgarden (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundgarden)
,
Alice in Chains (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_in_Chains)
,
Pearl Jam (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl_Jam)
, and
Mudhoney (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mudhoney)
, all of whom reached international audiences in the early 1990s.
[185] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Music-190)
The city is also home to such varied artists as
avant-garde jazz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avant-garde_jazz)
musicians
Bill Frisell (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Frisell)
and
Wayne Horvitz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wayne_Horvitz)
,
hot jazz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swing_music)
musician
Glenn Crytzer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glenn_Crytzer)
,
hip hop (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hip_hop_music)
artists
Sir Mix-a-Lot (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Mix-a-Lot)
,
Macklemore (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macklemore)
,
Blue Scholars (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Scholars)
, and
Shabazz Palaces (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shabazz_Palaces)
,
smooth jazz (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smooth_jazz)
saxophonist
Kenny G (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenny_G)
,
classic rock (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classic_rock)
staples
Heart (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heart_(band))
and
Queensrÿche (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queensr%C3%BFche)
, and alternative rock bands such as
Foo Fighters (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foo_Fighters)
,
Harvey Danger (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harvey_Danger)
,
The Presidents of the United States of America (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Presidents_of_the_United_States_of_America_(band))
,
The Posies (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Posies)
,
Modest Mouse (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modest_Mouse)
,
Band of Horses (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Band_of_Horses)
,
Death Cab for Cutie (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_Cab_for_Cutie)
, and
Fleet Foxes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fleet_Foxes)
. Rock musicians such as
Jimi Hendrix (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jimi_Hendrix)
,
Duff McKagan (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duff_McKagan)
, and
Nikki Sixx (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikki_Sixx)
spent their formative years in Seattle.
The Seattle-based
Sub Pop (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sub_Pop)
record company continues to be one of the world's best-known independent/alternative music labels.
[185] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Seattle_Music-190)
Seattle is known for its live-music venues including
The Crocodile (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Crocodile)
,
Vito's (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vito%27s)
and Columbia City Theater.
[186] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-191)
Over the years,
a number of songs have been written about Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_songs_about_Seattle)
.
Seattle annually sends a team of
spoken word (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoken_word)
slammers to the
National Poetry Slam (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Poetry_Slam)
and considers itself home to such performance poets as
Buddy Wakefield (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddy_Wakefield)
, two-time
Individual World Poetry Slam (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Individual_World_Poetry_Slam)
Champ;
[187] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-192)
Anis Mojgani (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anis_Mojgani)
, two-time National Poetry Slam Champ;
[188] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-193)
and
Danny Sherrard (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danny_Sherrard)
, 2007 National Poetry Slam Champ and 2008 Individual World Poetry Slam Champ.
[189] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-194)
Seattle also hosted the 2001 national Poetry Slam Tournament. The Seattle Poetry Festival is a biennial poetry festival that (launched first as the Poetry Circus in 1997) has featured local, regional, national, and international names in poetry.
[190] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-195)
The city also has movie houses showing both
Hollywood (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood,_Los_Angeles,_California)
productions and works by
independent filmmakers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_film)
.
[191] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-196)
Among these, the
Seattle Cinerama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Cinerama)
stands out as one of only three movie theaters in the world still capable of showing three-panel
Cinerama (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinerama)
films.
[192] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-197)
Tourism
See also:
List of museums in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Seattle)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Norwegian_Sun_in_Seattle,_Washington.jpg)
210 cruise ship visits brought 886,039 passengers to Seattle in 2008.
[193] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-198)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_Great_Wheel_Washington1.jpg)
The
Seattle Great Wheel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Great_Wheel)
Among Seattle's prominent annual fairs and festivals are the 24-day
Seattle International Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_International_Film_Festival)
,
[194] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-199)
Northwest Folklife over the
Memorial Day (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memorial_Day)
weekend, numerous
Seafair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafair)
events throughout July and August (ranging from a
Bon Odori (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bon_Odori)
celebration to the
Seafair Cup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafair_Cup)
hydroplane (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroplane_(boat))
races), the
Bite of Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bite_of_Seattle)
, one of the largest
Gay Pride (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Pride)
festivals in the United States, and the art and music festival
Bumbershoot (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bumbershoot)
, which programs music as well as other art and entertainment over the Labor Day weekend. All are typically attended by 100,000 people annually, as are the
Seattle Hempfest (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Hempfest)
and two separate
Independence Day (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independence_Day_(United_States))
celebrations.
[195] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-200)
[196] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-201)
[197] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-202)
[198] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-203)
Other significant events include numerous Native American
pow-wows (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pow-wow)
, a Greek Festival hosted by
St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Demetrios_Greek_Orthodox_Church_(Seattle))
in
Montlake (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montlake,_Seattle)
, and numerous ethnic festivals (many associated with
Festál at Seattle Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fest%C3%A1l_at_Seattle_Center)
).
[199] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-204)
There are other annual events, ranging from the Seattle Antiquarian Book Fair & Book Arts Show;
[200] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-205)
an
anime (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anime)
convention,
Sakura-Con (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sakura-Con)
;
[201] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-206)
Penny Arcade Expo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penny_Arcade_Expo)
, a gaming convention;
[202] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-207)
a two-day, 9,000-rider
Seattle to Portland Bicycle Classic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_to_Portland_Bicycle_Classic)
;
[203] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-208)
and specialized film festivals, such as the
Maelstrom International Fantastic Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maelstrom_International_Fantastic_Film_Festival)
, the
Seattle Asian American Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Asian_American_Film_Festival)
, Children's Film Festival Seattle, Translation: the Seattle Transgender Film Festival, the
Seattle Queer Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Queer_Film_Festival)
, Seattle Latino Film Festival, and the
Seattle Polish Film Festival (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Polish_Film_Festival)
.
[204] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-209)
[205] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-210)
The
Henry Art Gallery (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Art_Gallery)
opened in 1927, the first public art museum in Washington.
[206] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-211)
The
Seattle Art Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Art_Museum)
(SAM) opened in 1933 and moved to their current downtown location in 1991 (expanded and reopened in 2007); since 1991, the 1933 building has been SAM's
Seattle Asian Art Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Asian_Art_Museum)
(SAAM).
[207] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-212)
SAM also operates the
Olympic Sculpture Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympic_Sculpture_Park)
(opened in 2007) on the waterfront north of the downtown piers.
[208] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-213)
The
Frye Art Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frye_Art_Museum)
is a free museum on
First Hill (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Hill,_Seattle)
.
[209] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-214)
Regional history collections are at the Log House Museum in Alki,
Klondike Gold Rush National Historical Park (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klondike_Gold_Rush_National_Historical_Park)
, the
Museum of History and Industry (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_History_and_Industry)
, and the
Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burke_Museum_of_Natural_History_and_Culture)
. Industry collections are at the
Center for Wooden Boats (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Wooden_Boats)
and the adjacent
Northwest Seaport (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_Seaport)
, and the
Museum of Flight (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Flight)
. Regional ethnic collections include the
National Nordic Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Nordic_Museum)
, the
Wing Luke Asian Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wing_Luke_Asian_Museum)
, and the
Northwest African American Museum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northwest_African_American_Museum)
. Seattle has artist-run galleries,
[210] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-Scott2006-215)
including ten-year veteran Soil Art Gallery,
[211] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-216)
and the newer Crawl Space Gallery.
[212] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-217)
The
Seattle Great Wheel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Great_Wheel)
, one of the largest
Ferris wheels (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferris_wheel)
in the US, opened in June 2012 as a new, permanent attraction on the city's waterfront, at
Pier 57 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pier_57_(Seattle))
, next to
Downtown Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downtown_Seattle)
.
[213] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-great_wheel_opens-218)
The
Seattle Aquarium (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Aquarium)
opened on the downtown waterfront in 1977 and was expanded in 2007 with an auditorium, gift shop, and cafe alongside new exhibit spaces. A new, three-story building under the
Overlook Walk (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overlook_Walk)
opened in 2024 with tropical exhibits and a 500,000-US-gallon (1,900,000 L) tank with sharks and rays from the
Coral Triangle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coral_Triangle)
region of Southeast Asia.
[214] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-219)
[215] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-220)
Woodland Park Zoo (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Woodland_Park_Zoo)
opened as a private
menagerie (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menagerie)
in 1889 but was sold to the city in 1899.
[216] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-221)
The city also has many
community centers (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_centers_in_Seattle)
for recreation, including Rainier Beach, Van Asselt, Rainier, and Jefferson south of the Ship Canal and Green Lake, Laurelhurst, Loyal Heights north of the Canal, and Meadowbrook.
[217] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-222)
The
Seattle Underground (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Underground)
Tour is an exhibit of places that existed before the Great Fire and subsequent rebuilding of modern-day Pioneer Square, which raised the street level.
[218] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-223)
Since the mid-1990s, Seattle has experienced significant growth in the cruise industry, especially as a departure point for Alaska cruises. In 2023, a record total of 907,572 cruise passengers passed through the city, surpassing the number for Vancouver, BC, the other major departure point for Alaska cruises.
[219] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-224)
New tourist industries, such as guided tours and
amphibious tours (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duck_tour)
also emerged during the 1990s.
[220] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-225)
Libraries
Main article:
Seattle Public Library (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Public_Library)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Seattle_Library_01.jpg)
Seattle Central Library (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Central_Library)
The
Seattle Public Library (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Public_Library)
system consists of 27 branches with a combined total of 3,119,298 items as of 2023
[update] (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Seattle&action=edit)
.
[221] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-226)
The library was founded as part of the city government in 1890, though previous efforts to establish one date back to 1868; it first opened in 1891 and moved into a permanent location, a
mansion (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mansion)
once owned by Seattle pioneer
Henry Yesler (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Yesler)
, in 1899.
[222] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-SPL_central_1906_-_HL-227)
The mansion burned down in 1901 along with most of the 33,000 books then in the library's collection, resulting in the construction of a
Carnegie library (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_library)
building in 1906; eventually known as the
Seattle Central Library (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Central_Library)
, the building was replaced in 1960 with an
International Style (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Style)
design and again in 2004 with a design by Dutch architect
Rem Koolhaas (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rem_Koolhaas)
.
[222] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-SPL_central_1906_-_HL-227)
[223] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-228)
Religion
See also:
List of places of worship in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_places_of_worship_in_Seattle)
This section needs to be
updated
. The reason given is: This survey is more than eight years old.
Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.
(
December 2022
)
A 2024 Household Pulse Survey from the United States Census Bureau estimated that 64 percent of adults in the Seattle area never attend religious services or attend less than once a year, the highest percentage among large U.S. metropolitan areas.
[224] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-229)
According to a 2014 study by the
Pew Research Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center)
, the largest religious groupings are
Christians (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity)
(52%), followed by those of
no religion (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irreligion)
(37%),
Hindus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism)
(2%),
Buddhists (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism)
(2%),
Jews (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism)
(1%),
Muslims (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam)
(1%) and a variety of other religions have smaller followings.
[225] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-230)
According to the same study by the
Pew Research Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pew_Research_Center)
, about 34% of Seattleites are
Protestant (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protestant)
, and 15% are
Roman Catholic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Catholic)
. Meanwhile, 6% of the residents in Seattle call themselves
agnostics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agnostics)
, while 10% call themselves
atheists (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atheists)
.
[226] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle#cite_note-231)
