Left to right:
CN Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CN_Tower)
(Toronto),
Willis Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willis_Tower)
(Chicago),
Stratosphere (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Strat)
(Las Vegas), Space Needle
The architecture of the Space Needle is the result of a compromise between the designs of two people, Edward E. Carlson and John Graham, Jr. The two leading ideas for the World Fair involved businessman
Edward E. Carlson (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Carlson)
's sketch (on a napkin)
[7] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-7)
of a giant
balloon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balloon)
tethered to the ground (the gently sloping base) and architect
John Graham (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Graham,_Jr._(architect))
's concept of a
flying saucer (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flying_saucer)
(that houses the restaurant and observation deck).
Victor Steinbrueck (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victor_Steinbrueck)
introduced the hourglass profile of the tower and its tripod design, which resembles the
isthmus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isthmus)
that Seattle is situated on.
[8] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-8)
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Crosscut-Podcast-9)
The Space Needle was built to withstand
Category 5 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson_Hurricane_Scale)
-plus wind speeds of 200 mph (320 km/h), double the requirements in the building code of 1962, swaying only 1 inch (25 mm) per 10 miles per hour (16 km/h) of wind speed.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
While the 2001 6.8 M
w
Nisqually earthquake (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2001_Nisqually_earthquake)
jolted the Needle enough for water to slosh out of the toilets in the restrooms, the structure is designed to avoid serious structural damage in earthquakes of magnitudes below 9.1.
[10] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-10)
For decades, the hovering disk of the Space Needle was home to two restaurants 500 ft (150 m) above the ground: the Space Needle Restaurant, which was originally named Eye of the Needle, and Emerald Suite. These were closed in 2000 to make way for
SkyCity (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SkyCity)
, a larger restaurant featuring Pacific Northwest cuisine, which closed in 2017. In 1993, the elevators were replaced with new computerized versions. The new elevators descend at a rate of 10 mph (16 km/h).
On
December 31 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve)
, 1999, a powerful beam of light was unveiled for the first time. Known as the Legacy Light or Skybeam, it is powered by lamps that total 85 million
candela (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candela)
shining skyward from the top of the Space Needle to honor national holidays and special occasions in Seattle. The concept of this beam was derived from the
official 1962 World's Fair poster (https://digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/digital/collection/imlsmohai/id/22)
, which depicted such a light source (although none was incorporated into the building's original design). It is somewhat controversial because of the
light pollution (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_pollution)
it creates.
[11] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-11)
Originally planned to be turned on 75 nights per year, it has generally been used fewer than a dozen times per year. It did remain lit for eleven days in a row from September 11, 2001, to September 22, 2001, in response to the
September 11, 2001, attacks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11,_2001,_attacks)
.
[12] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-12)
[
unreliable source? (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources)
]
A 1962 Seattle World's Fair poster
[13] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-13)
showed a grand spiral entryway leading to the
elevator (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elevator)
that was ultimately omitted from final building plans.
[14] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-14)
[
better source needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)
]
The main stairwell has 848 steps from the basement to the top of the observation deck.
[15] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Funfacts-15)
At approximately 605 ft (184 m), the Space Needle was the tallest building west of the
Mississippi River (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mississippi_River)
at the time it was built by
Howard S. Wright (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_S._Wright)
Construction Co., but is now dwarfed by other structures along the Seattle skyline alone, among them the
Columbia Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_Center)
, at 967 ft (295 m).
[16] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-16)
Unlike many other similar structures, such as the
CN Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CN_Tower)
in Toronto, the Space Needle is not used for broadcasting purposes.
History
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=2)
]
Construction
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=3)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Space_Needle_under_construction,_1961_-_from_southeast.jpg)
Space Needle and various buildings for the
Seattle World's Fair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_World%27s_Fair)
under construction, 1961
Edward E. Carlson, chairman of the 1962
World's Fair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World%27s_Fair)
in Seattle, had an idea for erecting a tower with a restaurant at the World's Fair. The president of
Western International Hotels (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_International_Hotels)
, he had been inspired by a recent visit to the
Stuttgart Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fernsehturm_Stuttgart)
in
Germany (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany)
.
[17] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Chicago-1983-17)
[18] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-18)
Local architect John Graham soon became involved as a result of his success in designing
Northgate Mall (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northgate_Mall_(Seattle))
. Graham's first move was to alter the restaurant's original design to a
revolving restaurant (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revolving_restaurant)
, similar to his previous design of the
La Ronde (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Ronde_(restaurant))
tower restaurant at the
Ala Moana Center (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ala_Moana_Center)
in
Honolulu (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Honolulu)
.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
Among the names proposed for the structure by Carlson, Graham, and Steinbrueck were the "Space Needle", "Star Tickler", "Top Hat", and "Big
Skookum (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skookum)
".
[9] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Crosscut-Podcast-9)
The proposed Space Needle had no pre-selected site. Since it was not financed by the city, land had to be purchased within the fairgrounds. The investors had been unable to find suitable land and the search for a site was nearly dead when, in 1961, they discovered a lot, 120 by 120 ft (37 by 37 m), containing switching equipment for the fire and police alarm systems. The land, which originally had the neighborhood's fire station until 1921, was sold by the city for $75,000.
[19] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-19)
Geotechnical engineers quickly tested and approved the site for construction. At this point, only one year remained before the World's Fair would begin. The Needle was privately financed and built by the Pentagram Corporation, consisting of
Bagley Wright (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bagley_Wright)
, contractor
Howard S. Wright (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Howard_S._Wright)
, architect
John Graham (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Graham_%26_Associates)
,
Ned Skinner (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ned_Skinner)
, and
Norton Clapp (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norton_Clapp)
. In 1977, Bagley, Skinner, and Clapp sold their interest to the Howard Wright Company, which now controls it under the name of Space Needle Corporation.
[20] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-20)
The concrete base of the Space Needle is 30 ft (9.1 m) deep and 120 ft (37 m) across, and took 467 redi-mix trucks one full day to fill. The foundation weighs 5,850 short tons (5,310 metric tons) (including 250 short tons or 230 metric tons of reinforcing steel), the same as the above-ground structure. The tower is secured to the foundation with 72 30 ft (9.1 m) long bolts.
With time an issue, the construction team worked around the clock. The domed top, housing the top five levels (including the restaurants and observation deck), was perfectly balanced so that the restaurant could rotate with the help of one tiny electric motor, originally 0.8 kilowatts (1.1 hp), later replaced with a 1.1 kilowatts (1.5 hp) motor. Painted in Orbital Olive paint for the body, Astronaut White for the legs, Re-entry Red for the saucer, and Galaxy Gold for the roof, the Space Needle was finished in less than one year. It was completed in April 1962 at a cost of $4.5 million. The last elevator car was installed the day before the Fair opened on April 21. During the course of the Fair, nearly 20,000 people a day rode to the Observation Deck, culminating to a total of 2.56 million visitors.   Upon completion, the Space Needle was the tallest building west of the Mississippi River, replacing the
Kansas City Power and Light Building (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Power_and_Light_Building)
which had held that distinction since 1931. It also replaced the
Smith Tower (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smith_Tower)
in downtown Seattle as the tallest building on the American west coast, which it had been since 1914.
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Space_Needle_at_World%27s_Fair,_1962.jpg)
Completed Space Needle after the opening of the World's Fair - April 1962
The revolving restaurant was operated by Carlson's Western International Hotels
[21] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-21)
under a 20-year contract from April 1, 1962, to April 1, 1982.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
Carillon
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=4)
]
An
imitation carillon (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_carillon)
(using recordings of
bells (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell)
, rather than live bells) was installed in the Space Needle, and played several times a day during the World's Fair.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
The instrument, built by the Schulmerich Bells Company of
Hatfield, Pennsylvania (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hatfield,_Pennsylvania)
[22] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-22)
[23] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-23)
under the name "Carillon Americana", recreated the sounds of 538 bells and was the
largest in the world (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_carillons)
, until eclipsed by a 732 bell instrument at the
1964 New York World's Fair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair)
. The operator's console was located in the base of the Space Needle, completely enclosed in glass to allow observation of the musician playing the instrument. It was also capable of being played from a roll, like a player piano. The forty-four stentors (speakers) of the carillon were located underneath the Needle's disc at the 200-foot (61 m) level and were audible over the entire fairgrounds and up to ten miles (16 km) away.
[24] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-24)
The carillon was disassembled after the fair's close.
The Carillon Americana was featured on a 12-track
LP record (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LP_record)
called "Bells On High-Fi" (catalog number AR-8, produced by Americana Records, of
Sellersville, Pennsylvania (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sellersville,_Pennsylvania)
). These studio recordings were performed by noted
carillonneur (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carillonneur)
John Klein (1915–1981).
[25] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-25)
[26] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-26)
After the Fair
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=5)
]
A radio
broadcast studio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recording_studio)
was built on the observation level of the Space Needle in 1963.
[27] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-27)
It was used for morning broadcasts by
Radio KING (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KPTR_(AM)#KING)
and its sister TV station
KING-TV (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KING-TV)
from July 1963 to May 1966, and
KIRO Radio (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KIRO_(AM))
from 1966 to 1974.
[28] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-28)
Disc jockey Bobby Wooten of country music station
KAYO-AM (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KKNW)
lived in an apartment built adjacent to the Space Needle's broadcast studio for six months in 1974, which required a permit variance from the city government.
[29] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-29)
[30] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-30)
On March 27, 1964, the restaurant atop the Space Needle stopped rotating as a result of the
9.2 earthquake in Alaska (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_Alaska_earthquake)
.
[31] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-31)
In 1974, author
Stephen Cosgrove's (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Cosgrove_(writer))
children's book
Wheedle on the Needle
imagined a furry creature called the
Wheedle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheedle)
who lived on top of the Space Needle and caused its light to flash. Its closing quatrain is:
There's a Wheedle on the Needle / I know just what you're thinking / But if you look up late at night / You'll see his red nose blinking.
The Wheedle has since become a fixture of Seattle. It became the mascot of the
Seattle SuperSonics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics)
National Basketball Association (NBA) franchise, which played in nearby
KeyArena (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_Pledge_Arena)
(now Climate Pledge Arena). The
SuperSonics moved (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics_relocation_to_Oklahoma_City)
to
Oklahoma City (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oklahoma_City)
on July 3, 2008.
In 1982, the SkyLine level was added at the height of 100 ft (30 m). Although it was part of the original plans for the Space Needle, it was not built until that time. Today, the SkyLine Banquet Facility can accommodate groups of 20–360 people.
On April 19, 1999, the Space Needle was designated as a city historic landmark by the
Seattle Landmarks Preservation Board (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Landmarks_Preservation_Board)
37 years after it opened. It was the youngest historic landmark in the city.
[32] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-32)
Renovations were completed in 2000 at a cost ($21 million) approximately the same in inflated dollars as the original construction price. Renovations between 1999 and 2000 included the SkyCity restaurant, SpaceBase retail store, Skybeam installation, Observation Deck overhaul, lighting additions, and repainting.
On
New Year's Eve (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Year%27s_Eve)
, the Space Needle hosts a fireworks show at midnight;
Alberto Navarro (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alberto_Navarro)
, a fireworks artist from Bellevue, is the lead architect of the show, which is viewed by thousands from the Seattle Center grounds, and televised by
KING-TV (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KING-TV)
.
[33] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-33)
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:0-34)
In 2000, public celebrations were canceled because of perceived terror threats against the structure after investigations into the foiled
millennium bombing plots (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2000_millennium_attack_plots#LAX_bombing_plot)
, but the fireworks show was still held.
[35] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-35)
[36] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-36)
The 2020 fireworks display was canceled and replaced by a light show due to high winds,
[37] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-37)
while the 2021 display was canceled and replaced by a broadcast-only
augmented reality (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmented_reality)
show due to the
COVID-19 pandemic (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Washington_(state))
. The fireworks display returned for 2022, but the Seattle Center grounds were closed to the public due to state
proof of vaccination (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_passports_during_the_COVID-19_pandemic)
rules, and the television broadcast included augmented reality effects.
[34] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:0-34)
In 2002, a real estate consultant in
Bellevue (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bellevue,_Washington)
proposed the construction of five smaller replicas of the Space Needle around the city to promote tourism, though official plans to build the proposed structures have not yet materialized.
[38] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-38)
On May 19, 2007, the Space Needle welcomed its 45 millionth visitor, Greg Novoa from California, who received a free trip for two to
Paris (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris)
.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:1-39)
In May 2008, the Space Needle received its first professional deep cleaning since the opening of the 1962 World's Fair. The monument was pressure washed by
Kärcher (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%A4rcher)
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:2-40)
with water at a
pressure (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure)
of almost 2,611 psi (18,000 kPa) and a temperature of approximately 194 °F (90 °C). The cleaning was only done at night so that the Space Needle could stay open to the public. No detergents were used in consideration of the Seattle Center and the nearby
Experience Music Project (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture)
.
[41] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-41)
50th anniversary and renovation
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=6)
]
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Aerial_Space_Needle_Painted_Gold_May_2012.JPG)
Space Needle painted in "Galaxy Gold" for its 50th anniversary.
As part of the celebration of its 50th anniversary in April 2012, the roof of the Needle was painted "Galaxy Gold", which is more of an orangish color in practice. This is the same color used when the needle was originally constructed for the 1962 World's Fair.
[42] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-42)
This temporary makeover, intended to last through the summer, is not the Needle's first: it had the
University of Washington (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Washington)
(UW)
Huskies football team (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Huskies_football)
logo painted after the team won the
1992 Rose Bowl (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1992_Rose_Bowl)
; when the game show
Wheel of Fortune (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wheel_of_Fortune_(American_game_show))
taped episodes in Seattle in 1995, it was painted to resemble the titular wheel as part of an intro sequence with
Vanna White (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanna_White)
;
[43] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-43)
it was painted crimson after Washington State won the
Apple Cup (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apple_Cup)
;
[44] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-44)
was painted red, white, and blue for Memorial Day in 2003; and has been seen with the
Seattle SuperSonics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics)
and
Seattle Mariners (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_Mariners)
colors and logos.
[45] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-45)
The Galaxy Gold paint scheme returned for the Space Needle's 60th anniversary in May 2022 and was replaced a year later at a cost of $60,000 to $70,000.
[46] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-46)
[No Text] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Scaffold_on_Space_Needle_during_2017_renovation_06.jpg)
Scaffold surrounding top section during 2017–2018 renovation
A renovation of the top of the Space Needle began in the summer of 2017, to add an all-glass floor to the restaurant, replace the observation platform windows with floor-to-ceiling glass panels to more closely match the 1962 original concept sketches, as well as upgrade and update the internal systems.  Called the Century Project, the work was scheduled to finish by June 2018, at a cost of $100 million in private funds provided by the Wright family, who own the Space Needle.
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Greenstone2017-47)
The designer is
Olson Kundig Architects (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olson_Kundig_Architects)
and the general contractor is
Hoffman Construction Company (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoffman_Construction_Company)
. The rotating restaurant's motor was replaced, the elevator capacity was increased by adding elevators or double-stacking them, and the energy efficiency of the building was improved with the aim of achieving
LEED Gold Certification (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leadership_in_Energy_and_Environmental_Design)
. The temporary scaffold's 28,000-pound (13,000 kg), 44,650-square-foot (4,148 m
2
) platform under the top structure was assembled on the ground and then lifted by cables 500 ft (150 m) from the ground to the underside of the structure, controlled by 12 operators standing on the platform as it was raised. The platform was made by
Safway Services (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Safway_Services)
, a company specializing in unique construction scaffolding. One-sixth of the observation deck was closed at a time so that the Space Needle was never completely shut down to the public.
[47] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Greenstone2017-47)
[48] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Young2017-48)
[49] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-49)
[50] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Schlosser2017-50)
[51] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-51)
[52] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-smithsmag-52)
[
excessive citations (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Bundling_citations)
]
The space reopened in August 2018 as the Loupe, an indoor observation deck with a revolving glass floor. It takes 45 minutes for the observation deck to do a full rotation. Two sets of stairs called the Oculus Stairs were added to connect the two new levels. They were named after the glass oculus at the base of the stairs where the Space Needle elevators can be seen ascending and descending. A café, wine bar, more restrooms, and an additional accessibility elevator to the top observation deck were also added.
[53] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-OHare2018-53)
For the first several months of construction, a temporary enclosure was added above the roof.
[54] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-54)
Further renovations were made in 2025, including the addition of a revolving glass floor in the restaurant, new glass on the observation decks, and the first of three double-deck floor-to-ceiling glass elevators.
[39] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:1-39)
The renovation aimed to open up larger, panoramic views from both the top of the structure and from the elevators. The remaining two elevators are scheduled to be replaced, one each in 2027 and 2028.
[40] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-:2-40)
Jumping incidents
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=7)
]
Six parachutists have leaped from the tower since its opening, in a sport known as
BASE jumping (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BASE_jumping)
. This activity is legal only with prior authorization. Four of them were part of an authorized promotion in 1996, and one of the jumpers broke a bone in her back while attempting the stunt.
[55] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-55)
The other two jumped illegally and were arrested.
[56] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-56)
Paul D. Baker was the first person to jump from the Space Needle, committing suicide on March 4, 1974.
[57] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-oregonian-57)
Mary Lucille Wolf also jumped from the tower that year, on May 25.
[57] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-oregonian-57)
Following the two 1974 suicides, netting beneath and improved fencing around the observation deck were installed.
[58] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-58)
In spite of the barrier additions, however, another suicide by Dixie Reeder occurred on July 5, 1978.
[59] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-59)
Appearances in TV and film
[
edit (https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Space_Needle&action=edit&section=8)
]
As a symbol of the Pacific Northwest, the Space Needle has made numerous appearances in films, TV shows, and other works of fiction. The Space Needle is often used in
establishing shots (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Establishing_shot)
as an economical means of indicating the setting is Seattle.  Examples include the TV shows
Frasier (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frasier)
,
Grey's Anatomy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey%27s_Anatomy)
,
Dark Angel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_Angel_(2000_TV_series))
,
Bill Nye the Science Guy (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Nye_the_Science_Guy)
,  and films
It Happened at the World's Fair (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/It_Happened_at_the_World%27s_Fair)
(1962),
The Parallax View (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Parallax_View)
(1974), where it was used as a filming location,
Sleepless in Seattle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sleepless_in_Seattle)
(1993), and
Chronicle (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chronicle_(film))
(2012).
[60] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-60)
The 1999 film
Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austin_Powers:_The_Spy_Who_Shagged_Me)
made an absurdist visual gag conflating another icon of Seattle,
Starbucks (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starbucks)
, with the tower, showing the coffee chain's name written across the Space Needle's saucer placing the villain
Doctor Evil (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doctor_Evil)
's base of operations there after his henchman Number 2 shifted the organization's resources toward the coffee company.
[61] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Packer2009-61)
[62] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Zimmerman2012-62)
[63] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-Fellner2008-63)
As a visual symbol of Seattle, the Space Needle has been incorporated into the logos of
NBA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Basketball_Association)
(in various logos for the
Seattle SuperSonics (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seattle_SuperSonics)
from 1967 to 2001),
WNBA (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association)
,
MLS (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Major_League_Soccer)
, and
NHL (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Hockey_League)
professional sports teams.
[64] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-64)
[65] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-65)
The Space Needle has been involved in
practical jokes (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Practical_joke)
, especially those on
April Fools' Day (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_Fools%27_Day)
. In 1989,
KING-TV (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KING-TV)
's
Almost Live! (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Almost_Live!)
reported that the Space Needle had collapsed, causing panicked people to call emergency services and forcing the station to apologize afterwards;
[66] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-66)
the incident was compared to the
1938 radio broadcast (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds_(1938_radio_drama))
of
The War of the Worlds (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_War_of_the_Worlds)
, which caused panic among some listeners.
[67] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-67)
[68] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-68)
On April 1, 2015, public radio station
KPLU (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KNKX)
reported that a
hoax (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hoax)
sign had been erected by a group calling itself the "
Borg (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Borg)
Collective", depicting a fake proposed land use action "to construct a 666 unit cube to assimilate" the landmark.
[69] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-69)
Other TV appearances include
The History Channel (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_(U.S._TV_network))
's
Life After People (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_After_People)
, in which the tower collapses after 200 years because of
corrosion (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corrosion)
.
[70] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-70)
The tower was also destroyed in the TV miniseries
10.5 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10.5_(TV_miniseries))
when a 7.9 earthquake hits Seattle.
[71] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-71)
The miniseries mistakenly portrays the Needle as crumbling concrete, though the structure is actually made of steel and designed to withstand up to a 9.0 earthquake.
[
citation needed (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)
]
The Space Needle was also the site of the first task for the finale of
The Amazing Race 35 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Amazing_Race_35)
, where contestants had to walk atop its roof.
[72] (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_Needle#cite_note-72)
The Space Needle features in the
HBO (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO)
series
The Last of Us (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Last_of_Us_(TV_series))
as a watchtower in a post-apocalyptic version of Seattle, a major setting of the second season. It played a similar role in the video game
The Last of Us Part II (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Last_of_Us_Part_II)
, which serves as source material for the TV series.
